urn:contentItem:6GSH-J2X3-RTWD-D022-00000-00Caution urged as fire risk returns Fires Record wildfires in state last fall, with 500 acres burned2025-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisMAINPg. A3Caution urged as fire risk returns Fires Record wildfires in state last fall, with 500 acres burnedStephen Underwood Hartford Courant

As wildfire season in Connecticut begins in October through the first snowfall, the Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection is urging residents to remain cautious and proactive to minimize fire risks.

Over the next few weeks, dry and windy weather conditions, combined with fallen leaves and increased sunlight reaching and warming the forest floor, can elevate the likelihood of wildfires, according to state officials.

Connecticut experienced record wildfires last fall, with 605 fires burning more than 500 acres, destroying eight structures and disrupting communities across the state, a spokesperson with DEEP said. Last year, Gov. Ned Lamont declared a state of emergency, issued a statewide burn ban and activated the Northeast Forest Fire Protection Compact, bringing in support from other states and the National Guard. During the last wildlife season, eight firefighters were injured and one firefighter, Robert Sharkevich Sr., lost his life while battling the Hawthorne fire on Lamentation Mountain in Berlin.

"The statewide emergency last fall was a stark reminder of the dangers wildfires pose in Connecticut," said DEEP commissioner Katie Dykes. "Last year, our firefighting capabilities were stretched to the limit, requiring assistance from other states and Canada. We all share responsibility for preventing wildfires, and in doing so, we help keep our first responders and our neighbors safe.

"We ask everyone to be extra vigilant this season by staying informed about the daily fire danger level and local open burning laws, properly attending to outdoor fires at home or when out camping, carefully disposing of home heating ash and smoking materials, and exercising caution with machinery and equipment that could spark near dry grass and leaves," Dykes said.

Connecticut's fire risk is increasing as climate change drives more extreme weather patterns, which at times can include drier conditions, hotter temperatures and stronger winds - all of which are risk factors for wildfire, according to DEEP. Simultaneously, various forest pests and disease are also increasing the number of dead trees on the Connecticut landscape, further increasing the forests' vulnerability to wildfires.

According to the U.S. Drought Monitor, nearly half of the state, including Fairfield and New London counties, are experiencing "abnormally dry" conditions. Parts of Hartford County are experiencing dry conditions, according to the monitor. The Forest Fire Danger Level remains "moderate" for the entire state as dry conditions persist.

Almost all wildfires are caused by humans and are therefore preventable, DEEP said. Maintaining awareness of fire danger and observing appropriate precaution are things that everyone can do to minimize the likelihood of starting a dangerous wildfire.

DEEP's Forest Fire Control Office urges anyone who uses the state's parks, forests and open spaces to use fire with caution and heed the following recommendations, especially during forest fire season:

Obey local laws regarding open fires, including campfires.

Keep all flammable objects away from fire. Scrape away leaves, twigs and grass within a 10-foot diameter circle from fire.

Have firefighting tools nearby and handy.

Never leave a fire unattended.

Carefully dispose of hot coal/ashes.

Drown all fires.

Carefully extinguish smoking materials.

For Connecticut homeowners, DEEP recommends the following steps to protect family members and the home:

Make a fire-safe zone around your house. Clean flammable vegetation and debris from at least 30 feet around the house and any outbuildings.

Prune away the lower limbs of evergreens that are within the fire-safe zone. Evergreens catch fire easily during dry periods and burn quickly.

Remove any limbs which overhang the roof or chimney.

Regularly remove leaves and needles from gutters.

Do not store firewood in the fire-safe zone.

Use fire-resistant roofing materials.

Make sure firefighters can find and access your home. Mark your house and roads clearly and prune away limbs and trees along your driveway that do not allow fire truck access.

Have an escape plan and practice it.

Follow state and local open burning laws.

Stay with outside fires until they are completely safe and extinguished.

Dispose of wood ashes in a metal bucket and soak them with water before dumping them.

"If you spot a wildfire, remain calm, go to the nearest telephone, and dial 911 to report the fire as quickly as possible to your local fire department," according to DEEP. "Tell the emergency dispatcher when and where you saw the fire. If you see anything suspicious at or near the scene of the fire, take note and relay that to the dispatcher as well. Stay on the telephone until the dispatcher tells you to hang up."

For more information on Connecticut's wildfire season, go to portal.ct.gov/deep/forestry.

urn:contentItem:6GRN-SV33-RXJ5-83HM-00000-00Controlled the fire declared last Friday in the Teliarán reservoir, in Calañas.2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisControlled the fire declared last Friday in the Teliarán reservoir, in Calañas.


The Forest Fire Fighting Service of Andalusia, the Infoca Plan, has managed to control Sunday the fire declared last Friday in the Teliarán Reservoir, in the municipality of Calañas (Huelva).


As reported by the Forest Fire Fighting Service of Andalusia in its official account of 'X' (formerly Twitter), consulted by Europa Press, the fire has been controlled about 18.45 hours in the afternoon by the troops of this service. Before reaching this stage, the Minister of Presidency, Interior, Social Dialogue and Administrative Simplification, Antonio Sanz, reported last day the emergency phase, operational situation 1 of Plan Infoca, in the area.
At present, the Infoca troops continue to perform their work of auctioning and liquidation on the area affected by the flames to finally extinguish the fire.
It should be recalled that the Infoca Plan deployed for stabilization a device of troops to work on the affected terrain composed of a semi-heavy helicopter; five fire engines; 35 forest firefighters; a firefighting technician; three operations technicians; two emergency managers; an environmental agent; an analysis unit and a bulldozer.
UP TO THIRTEEN AERIAL RESOURCES DEPLOYED
During the day on Friday, have come to deploy up to thirteen aerial means and seven fire engines with six groups of specialists, as well as the Regional Group of Forest Fire Command (Gremaf), four technical operations, an environmental agent, the Mobile Unit of Meteorology and Transmissions, along with the Medical Unit in Forest Fires (UMIF).
The emergency telephone 112 began receiving notices from citizens alerting the fire about 15.40 hours and, after that, alerted the Civil Guard, the Local Police, as well as the troops of the Provincial Fire Consortium of Huelva, the Provincial Operational Center (COP) Infoca and the National Police Unit attached to the autonomous community. According to sources in the direction of extinction, the fire spread through an area of pasture due to wind gusts of more than 15 kilometers per hour in the area.
For its part, the Consortium of Firefighters has explained that the fire has originated near the H-15101, in an area of solar panels. To the area have moved the parks of Minas de Riotinto and Valverde del Camino, with four trucks and six firefighters.
Also, the mayor of Calañas, Diego Carrasco, through the social networks of the City Council has explained that the fire is near the urban core, but "all air and ground means" are working. Therefore, the mayor asked for "caution" and "calm" to the neighbors, since he has recommended to the neighbors not to approach the area, as well as "to collect awnings and close windows for safety".
Also, the website of the DGT reported that the road HU-5101 had been completely cut, at kilometer 2 in both directions, so it was requested to exercise extreme caution and avoid the area.

urn:contentItem:6GCH-0S53-S40T-243B-00000-00University of Southern Queensland Researchers Yield New Data on Remote Sensing [Predictive Assessment of Forest Fire Risk in the Hindu Kush Himalaya (HKH) Region Using HIWAT Data Integration]2025-07-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGUniversity of Southern Queensland Researchers Yield New Data on Remote Sensing [Predictive Assessment of Forest Fire Risk in the Hindu Kush Himalaya (HKH) Region Using HIWAT Data Integration]


2025 JUL 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in remote sensing. According to news reporting from Toowoomba, Australia, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires in the Hindu Kush Himalaya (HKH) region are increasing in frequency and severity, driven by climate variability, prolonged dry periods, and human activity. Nepal, a critical part of the HKH, recorded over 22,700 forest fire events in the past decade, with fire incidence nearly doubling in 2023."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from University of Southern Queensland: "Despite this growing threat, operational early warning systems remain limited. This study presents Nepal's first high-resolution early fire risk outlook system, developed by adopting the Canadian Fire Weather Index (FWI) using meteorological forecasts from the High-Impact Weather Assessment Toolkit (HIWAT). The system generates daily and two-day forecasts using a fully automated Python-based workflow and publishes results as Web Map Services (WMS). Model validation against MODIS, VIIRS, and ground fire records for 2023 showed that over 80% of fires occurred in zones classified as Moderate to Very High risk. Spatiotemporal analysis confirmed fire seasonality, with peaks in mid-April and over 65% of fires occurring in forested areas. The system's integration of satellite data and high-resolution forecasts improves the spatial and temporal accuracy of fire danger predictions."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This research presents a novel, scalable, and operational framework tailored for data-scarce and topographically complex regions. Its transferability holds substantial potential for strengthening anticipatory fire management and climate adaptation strategies across the HKH and beyond."
For more information on this research see: Predictive Assessment of Forest Fire Risk in the Hindu Kush Himalaya (HKH) Region Using HIWAT Data Integration. Remote Sensing, 2025,17(13):2255. (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/rs17132255.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Sunil Thapa, Institute for Life Sciences and the Environment (ILSE), University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, QLD 4350, Australia. Additional authors for this research include Tek Maraseni, Hari Krishna Dhonju, Kiran Shakya, Bikram Shakya, Armando Apan, Bikram Banerjee.
Keywords for this news article include: University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, Australia, Australia and New Zealand, Remote Sensing, Technology.

urn:contentItem:6GNC-XGJ3-RTD4-P0W1-00000-00COMSATS University Islamabad Researchers Detail New Studies and Findings in the Area of Physics (FireNet-KD: Swin Transformer-Based Wildfire Detection with Multi-Source Knowledge Distillation)2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisPHYSICSCOMSATS University Islamabad Researchers Detail New Studies and Findings in the Area of Physics (FireNet-KD: Swin Transformer-Based Wildfire Detection with Multi-Source Knowledge Distillation)


2025 SEP 04 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Research findings on physics are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting out of Islamabad, Pakistan, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fire detection is an essential application in environmental surveillance since wildfires cause devastating damage to ecosystems, human life, and property every year. The effective and accurate detection of fire is necessary to allow for timely response and efficient management of disasters."


Funders for this research include Princess Princess Nourah Bint Abdulrahman University Researchers Supporting Project.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from COMSATS University Islamabad: "Traditional techniques for fire detection often experience false alarms and delayed responses in various environmental situations. Therefore, developing robust, intelligent, and real-time detection systems has emerged as a central challenge in remote sensing and computer vision research communities. Despite recent achievements in deep learning, current forest fire detection models still face issues with generalizability, lightweight deployment, and accuracy trade-offs. In order to overcome these limitations, we introduce a novel technique (FireNet-KD) that makes use of knowledge distillation, a method that maps the learning of hard models (teachers) to a light and efficient model (student). We specifically utilize two opposing teacher networks: a Vision Transformer (ViT), which is popular for its global attention and contextual learning ability, and a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), which is esteemed for its spatial locality and inductive biases. These teacher models instruct the learning of a Swin Transformer-based student model that provides hierarchical feature extraction and computational efficiency through shifted window self-attention, and is thus particularly well suited for scalable forest fire detection. By combining the strengths of ViT and CNN with distillation into the Swin Transformer, the FireNet-KD model outperforms state-of-the-art methods with significant improvements."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Experimental results show that the FireNet-KD model obtains a precision of 95.16%, recall of 99.61%, F1-score of 97.34%, and mAP@50 of 97.31%, outperforming the existing models. These results prove the effectiveness of FireNet-KD in improving both detection accuracy and model efficiency for forest fire detection."
For more information on this research see: FireNet-KD: Swin Transformer-Based Wildfire Detection with Multi-Source Knowledge Distillation. Fire, 2025,8(8):295. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8080295.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Naveed Ahmad, Department of Computer Science, COMSATS University Islamabad, Islamabad 44000, Pakistan. Additional authors for this research include Mariam Akbar, Eman H. Alkhammash, Mona M. Jamjoom.
Keywords for this news article include: COMSATS University Islamabad, Islamabad, Pakistan, Asia, Physics.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5F03-S5NX-F0NX-00000-00Only active fire in Bolivia is registered in the Ñembi Guasu reserve2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisOnly active fire in Bolivia is registered in the Ñembi Guasu reserve


Bolivia is currently facing a single active forest fire, located in the Ñembi Guasu reserve in the department of Santa Cruz. Firefighters are working hard to extinguish the flames and, at the same time, protect the most vulnerable areas of this conservation zone, which is under the Charagua Iyambae Indigenous Autonomy. This information was provided by the Vice-Minister of Civil Defense, Juan Carlos Calvimontes.


Calvimontes indicated that, at the close of Monday, September 1, a total of 1,462 hot spots were registered throughout the national territory. Most of these outbreaks are concentrated in Santa Cruz, with 684, followed by Beni with 584, Pando with 93, Cochabamba with 19, Potosí with 15, Chuquisaca with 12 and Oruro with 7.
Fires and controlled burns
The Vice-Minister clarified that the presence of active fire does not always mean that there is a forest fire. In many cases, they are controlled grassland burns, such as those that have been verified in San Ramón, Beni.
Chaqueo activity in Pando
In addition, chaqueo activity has been reported in Bolpebra, Pando. This practice continues despite restrictions and represents a significant risk for the region. Calvimontes explained that the fires that previously affected Toro Toro, in northern Potosí, as well as Carmen Rivero Torres and San Ignacio de Velasco, in Santa Cruz, have been controlled and are currently in the cooling stage.
Work in the Ñembi Guasu reserve
The only forest fire that is still active is in Ñembi Guasu, where emergency crews continue to extinguish it. Their objective is to protect the reserve and nearby communities. The authority emphasized that the constant work is aimed at avoiding the spread of the flames and guaranteeing effective control of the situation.
LDVY
The post The only active fire in Bolivia is registered in the Ñembi Guasu reserve first appeared on Periódico La Patria.

urn:contentItem:6GSC-9XN3-RS9N-53YD-00000-00As CT's fire risk increases, officials are urging caution following record wildfires last fall2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSAs CT's fire risk increases, officials are urging caution following record wildfires last fallStephen UnderwoodHartford Courant

As wildfire season in Connecticut begins in October through the first snowfall, the Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection is urging residents to remain cautious and proactive to minimize fire risks.

Over the next few weeks, dry and windy weather conditions, combined with fallen leaves and increased sunlight reaching and warming the forest floor, can elevate the likelihood of wildfires, according to state officials.

Connecticut experienced record wildfires last fall, with 605 fires burning more than 500 acres, destroying eight structures and disrupting communities across the state, a spokesperson with DEEP said. Last year, Gov. Ned Lamont declared a state of emergency, issued a statewide burn ban and activated the Northeast Forest Fire Protection Compact, bringing in support from other states and the National Guard. During the last wildlife season, eight firefighters were injured and one firefighter, Robert Sharkevich Sr., lost his life while battling the Hawthorne fire on Lamentation Mountain in Berlin.

“The statewide emergency last fall was a stark reminder of the dangers wildfires pose in Connecticut,” said DEEP commissioner Katie Dykes. “Last year, our firefighting capabilities were stretched to the limit, requiring assistance from other states and Canada. We all share responsibility for preventing wildfires, and in doing so, we help keep our first responders and our neighbors safe.

"We ask everyone to be extra vigilant this season by staying informed about the daily fire danger level and local open burning laws, properly attending to outdoor fires at home or when out camping, carefully disposing of home heating ash and smoking materials, and exercising caution with machinery and equipment that could spark near dry grass and leaves," Dykes said.

Connecticut’s fire risk is increasing as climate change drives more extreme weather patterns, which at times can include drier conditions, hotter temperatures and stronger winds — all of which are risk factors for wildfire, according to DEEP. Simultaneously, various forest pests and disease are also increasing the number of dead trees on the Connecticut landscape, further increasing the forests' vulnerability to wildfires.

According to the U.S. Drought Monitor, nearly half of the state, including Fairfield and New London counties, are experiencing "abnormally dry" conditions. Parts of Hartford County are experiencing dry conditions, according to the monitor. The Forest Fire Danger Level remains “moderate” for the entire state as dry conditions persist.

Almost all wildfires are caused by humans and are therefore preventable, DEEP said. Maintaining awareness of fire danger and observing appropriate precaution are things that everyone can do to minimize the likelihood of starting a dangerous wildfire.

DEEP’s Forest Fire Control Office urges anyone who uses the state’s parks, forests and open spaces to use fire with caution and heed the following recommendations, especially during forest fire season:

Obey local laws regarding open fires, including campfires.

Keep all flammable objects away from fire. Scrape away leaves, twigs and grass within a 10-foot diameter circle from fire.

Have firefighting tools nearby and handy.

Never leave a fire unattended.

Carefully dispose of hot coal/ashes.

Drown all fires.

Carefully extinguish smoking materials.

For Connecticut homeowners, DEEP recommends the following steps to protect family members and the home:

Make a fire-safe zone around your house. Clean flammable vegetation and debris from at least 30 feet around the house and any outbuildings.

Prune away the lower limbs of evergreens that are within the fire-safe zone. Evergreens catch fire easily during dry periods and burn quickly.

Remove any limbs which overhang the roof or chimney.

Regularly remove leaves and needles from gutters.

Do not store firewood in the fire-safe zone.

Use fire-resistant roofing materials.

Make sure firefighters can find and access your home. Mark your house and roads clearly and prune away limbs and trees along your driveway that do not allow fire truck access.

Have an escape plan and practice it.

Follow state and local open burning laws.

Stay with outside fires until they are completely safe and extinguished.

Dispose of wood ashes in a metal bucket and soak them with water before dumping them.

"If you spot a wildfire, remain calm, go to the nearest telephone, and dial 911 to report the fire as quickly as possible to your local fire department," according to DEEP. "Tell the emergency dispatcher when and where you saw the fire. If you see anything suspicious at or near the scene of the fire, take note and relay that to the dispatcher as well. Stay on the telephone until the dispatcher tells you to hang up."

For more information on Connecticut's wildfire season, go to portal.ct.gov/deep/forestry.

Stephen Underwood can be reached at sunderwood@courant.com

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9VM3-RXXX-8215-00000-00These are the fastest plants to sprout after a forest fire2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisThese are the fastest plants to sprout after a forest fire


Forest fires have become one of the most worrying environmental emergencies every summer in Spain. Thousands of hectares of forest burn every year, leaving behind a desolate landscape of blackened trunks and ashes that seem to herald the end of all life. Even so, nature has an ace up its sleeve: the ability to regenerate itself. Just a few months after a fire, small green shoots begin to emerge from the scorched ground, reminding us that the cycle of life persists even in the most dramatic scenarios.


What at first glance might appear to be a miracle is, in reality, the fruit of millions of years of adaptation. In Mediterranean ecosystems, fire is not a foreign agent, but a recurrent element with which many species have learned to coexist. Some have developed seeds protected by such hard covers that only extreme heat can open them. Others store reserves in roots and rhizomes that, after a fire, allow them to resprout quickly.
Ecologists call these species "pioneers" because they are the first to occupy the devastated land. Their role is crucial: they help fix the soil, hinder erosion, retain moisture and create the necessary conditions for shrubs and larger trees to grow back over time.
Among the plants that appear most quickly after a fire are annual grasses and grasses. Thanks to their rapid germination and the ease with which their seeds disperse, they cover the soil in the weeks following the fire, providing food for small herbivores and slowing the advance of erosion.
In more humid and mountainous areas, ferns are a classic of early recovery. Their spores, resistant and abundant, find in the ashes a substrate full of nutrients to spread in a short time.
The Mediterranean ecosystem provides a range of species adapted like few others to fire. The rockroses germinate better after intense heat, while the broom resprouts vigorously from the roots. The fan palm, the only palm tree native to Europe, is surprisingly hardy: it withstands high temperatures, poor soils and even fires, forming dense stands that cover burned areas with green barely a year later.
The turn of the trees comes from species such as the resin pine, whose serotinous cones release their seeds only after exposure to the heat of the flames. Quercus (holm oaks, oaks or cork oaks) also demonstrate a great capacity for resistance: even if their crowns are destroyed, their deep roots conserve enough energy to send out new green shoots in a matter of months.
The future of forests
The dynamics of natural regeneration has, until now, been an effective mechanism for maintaining forest diversity and stability. However, the equation is changing. The climate crisis is leading to larger, more intense and much more rapidly spreading fires. Under these conditions, soils can become so eroded or overheated that seeds cannot survive.

urn:contentItem:6GGV-PHF3-RW2W-G3DX-00000-00Wenatchee skies haze over as Olympic National Forest fire spreads smoke across Washington2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSWenatchee skies haze over as Olympic National Forest fire spreads smoke across WashingtonJenni RodasThe Wenatchee World, Wash.

Wenatchee’s streak of smoke-free skies is over as winds push haze from a fire in the Olympic National Forest across the state.

The smoke appears to have originated from the Bear Gulch Fire burning near Lake Cushman, according to Washington Smoke Blog.

The Air Quality Index in Wenatchee is moderate, with a reading of 69, according to the U.S. Interagency Wildland Fire Air Quality Response Program.

When air quality is “moderate,” those who are more sensitive to smoke should cut back on time outside or skip heavy outdoor activity. Paper dust masks and standard surgical masks, like the ones used during the COVID-19 pandemic, won’t keep wildfire smoke out of your lungs.

This week, temperatures will dip into the 80s and 70s, with rain forecasted for Friday and Saturday.

The Bear Gulch Fire is one of five currently burning in the state, with the closest one being the Pomas Fire, burning 36 miles northwest of Entiat.

The Bear Gulch Fire, located deep in the forest near Lake Cushman, ignited on July 6. It has burned around 5,777 acres and is 3% contained, according to Northwest Team 7 Incident Management.

Crews are working near Mt. Rose and Lake Cushman to slow the fire’s spread and protect structures, using helicopters, heavy equipment, and sprinkler systems.

Fire managers anticipate continued surface spread, uphill runs, and isolated torching, with rolling debris and falling trees on steep slopes adding to the risk.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G53-RTHS-X43H-00000-00Conflict between Guardia Civil and Police over forest fire investigation2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisConflict between Guardia Civil and Police over forest fire investigation


The same investigated by National Police and Civil Guard. This conflict and clash of powers has occurred in recent weeks in Andalusia, according to police sources inform LA RAZÓN. The commanders of the corps have sent instructions on how to proceed but "clashes" continue to occur.


This has occurred mainly in the province of Almería. In this place there have been several conflicts between the Seprona of the Guardia Civil and the attached unit of the National Police Corps of Andalusia.
There have been cases in which both police forces have been investigating the same matter. Although instructions have already been issued in this regard, clashes continue to occur, these sources point out.
The conflicts are one of the points that are revealed in a document on the situation of the Seprona of the Civil Guard, to which this medium has had access. Because the agents specialized in combating environmental crimes have long been denouncing the restructuring of the area and the problematic consequences arising from this decision.
The explanation given by the commanders is that the specialty of Seprona has been immersed for some time in a situation in which an imminent restructuring or modification of the current configuration at the national level was perceived. With the latest announcement of vacancies, published on April 8, these changes seem to be effective.
The fact is that the components of the area have not been informed at any time of how their jobs would be and what alternatives are offered to them, with the consequent personal, economic and family damage. These changes affect units in which they would be eliminated and others in which they would be restructured.
A serious problem in Andalusia
One of the regions most affected by this problem is Andalusia. So far this year the Seprona of the Guardia Civil has been directly involved in 4 confirmed arrests for forest fires in 2025. All this, despite the adversities with which they have to carry out their work.
In order to carry out the closure of the units all vacancies in the unit are not published and are left to die. Another method is that these vacancies are "blocked" and are not advertised in the competitions. At the same time, the officers have to wear deteriorated suits and boots that are taking an average of three years to arrive.
In the same way, prevention work is not carried out in rural areas, due to the bureaucratic workload and the lack of personnel. In other places, such as Cadiz, they suffer from the usual and widespread double dependence on the territorial company and the Seprona. The former come out on top because of their interest in the Citizen Security statistics.
In short, the report details that the templates have a greater workload while losing troops and contact with citizens. A common denominator that has been occurring in Seprona agents throughout Spain.
Meetings to save Seprona
One of the most immediate consequences is the impact on environmental protection. The reduction of personnel limits the capacity to respond to forest fires, environmental crimes, poaching, illegal dumping or irregular constructions.
On the other hand, the last of the movements that has occurred to defend the Seprona has been made by the Professional Association of Corporals (APC) of the Civil Guard. This Tuesday, members of this entity met with the representative of Vox in the Parliament of Andalusia.
The objective of this meeting was to "address a matter of maximum social and environmental relevance such as forest fires and the existing problems with the Seprona". "Especially the restructuring and how this can affect crimes," they detailed in a publication in 'X' with photographs of the appointment.

urn:contentItem:6GM4-37M3-S4GW-73C8-00000-00Russia: What is known about Gelendzhik wildfire sparked by drone debris2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisGENERAL NEWSRussia: What is known about Gelendzhik wildfire sparked by drone debris

Falling drone debris caused a wildfire in Russia's southern city of Gelendzhik, which initially engulfed 200 square meters, the Krasnodar Region's crisis center said.

The blaze left 23 people trapped on the Black Sea coast near Gelendzhik, and a boat was sent to evacuate them.

TASS has gathered the key information about the incident.

Latest updates

- The fire has now expanded to cover an area of 3.2 hectares.

- Firefighting efforts involve over 40 personnel and 11 pieces of equipment.

- The airmobile team of the Russian Emergencies Ministry in the Krasnodar Region, which consists of 40 personnel and five pieces of equipment, has been put on high alert, the ministry said.

- An Mi-8 helicopter of the Russian Emergencies Ministry has joined the work to extinguish the forest fire near Gelendzhik.

- According to Gelendzhik Mayor Alexey Bogodistov, efforts to put out the blaze involve about 100 people and over 20 pieces of equipment.

Evacuation of tourists

- Twenty-three tourists vacationing on the Black Sea coast in the forest fire area were trapped, the Emergencies Ministry said.

- The ministry's State Inspection Department for Small Vessels sent a boat to evacuate them to a safe place.

- A holiday camp located near the forest scorched by the fire is being evacuated, Bogodistov said.

- A temporary accommodation center has been set up at a local school.

Forest fire

- The fire broke out in a forest near the settlement of Krinitsa in Gelendzhik, the regional crisis center reported.

- Three seats of fire were detected, engulfing a total of 200 square meters.

- According to the report, firefighting activities involve 14 personnel and four pieces of equipment.

- The fire expanded to about 0.7 hectares by 6:45 a.m. Moscow time (3:45 a.m. GMT). A set of measures is being taken to contain the wildfire, particularly through the deployment of additional forces and means.

- There were no casualties; emergency services are working at the site.

Source: Russian News Agency

urn:contentItem:6GGP-JJ53-RY2R-V1J3-00000-00Research Conducted at University of California Has Provided New Information about Climate Change (Climate Change Has Increased the Odds of Extreme Regional Forest Fire Years Globally)2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEResearch Conducted at University of California Has Provided New Information about Climate Change (Climate Change Has Increased the Odds of Extreme Regional Forest Fire Years Globally)


2025 AUG 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Research findings on Climate Change are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting from Merced, California, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Regions across the globe have experienced devastating fire years in the past decade with far-reaching impacts. Here, we examine the role of antecedent and concurrent climate variability in enabling extreme regional fire years across global forests."


Funders for this research include National Science Foundation, Department of Interior's Joint Fire Science Program, RCUK | Natural Environment Research Council.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of California, "These extreme years commonly coincided with extreme (1-in-15-year) fire weather indices (FWI) and featured a four and five-fold increase in the number of large fires and fire carbon emissions, respectively, compared with non-extreme years. Years with such extreme FWI metrics are 88-152% more likely across global forested lands under a contemporary (2011-2040) climate compared to a quasi-preindustrial (1851-1900) climate, with the most pronounced increased risk in temperate and Amazonian forests."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Our results show that human-caused climate change is raising the odds of extreme climate-driven fire years across forested regions of the globe, necessitating proactive measures to mitigate risks and adapt to extreme fire years."
For more information on this research see: Climate Change Has Increased the Odds of Extreme Regional Forest Fire Years Globally. Nature Communications, 2025;16(1). Nature Communications can be contacted at: Nature Portfolio, Heidelberger Platz 3, Berlin, 14197, Germany. (Nature Publishing Group - www.nature.com/; Nature Communications - www.nature.com/ncomms/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting John T. Abatzoglou, University of California, School of Engineering, Merced, CA 95343, United States. Additional authors for this research include Crystal A. Kolden, Alison C. Cullen, Mojtaba Sadegh, Emily L. Williams, Marco Turco and Matthew W. Jones.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-025-61608-1. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Merced, California, United States, North and Central America, Climate Change, Global Warming, University of California.

urn:contentItem:6GPD-3TS3-RTWG-C1B2-00000-00CPO FUTURES CLOSE HIGHER ON FOREST FIRE, WEAKER OUTPUT CONCERNS2025-07-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisCPO FUTURES CLOSE HIGHER ON FOREST FIRE, WEAKER OUTPUT CONCERNSNUR ATHIRAH BINTI MOHD SHAHARUDDINKUALA LUMPUR July 30

The crude palm oil (CPO) futures contract on Bursa Malaysia Derivatives ended higher today due to forest fires in North Sumatra, a dealer said.

Palm oil trader David Ng said the situation may hamper production in the medium term, likely by the end of this year or early next year.

"We locate support at RM4,200 and resistance at RM4,350 per tonne," he told Bernama.

Echoing the sentiment, Mumbai-based Sunvin Group commodity research head Anilkumar Bagani said Indonesia's declaration of a state of emergency in North Sumatra has introduced fresh supply concerns, contributing to market recovery from Tuesday onward.

Looking ahead, he said the potential upward revision of Indonesian palm oil export taxes and levies hinges on prices remaining above RM4,200 per tonne over the next fortnight.

"Such adjustments would indirectly support Malaysian palm oil by improving its relative pricing and export attractiveness," he said.

At the close, the spot-month August contract gained RM21 to RM4,209 per tonne, September 2025 added RM23 to RM4,254 per tonne and October 2025 edged up RM24 to RM4,278 per tonne.

The November 2025 contract increased RM24 to RM4,293 per tonne, December 2025 climbed RM23 to RM4,302 per tonne and January 2026 was up RM23 to RM4,307 per tonne.

Trading volume fell to 59,067 lots from 61,890 lots on Tuesday, while open interest increased to 224,701 contracts from 224,301 contracts previously.

The physical CPO price for August South rose RM20 to RM4,230 per tonne.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCG3-RSGF-H316-00000-00In 2025, Spain will have the hottest summer on record, says state agency2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisIn 2025, Spain will have the hottest summer on record, says state agency


This year's summer is already considered to be the hottest in Spain since the state meteorological agency AEMET began keeping records in 1961.
The country faced more than a month of heatwaves caused by climate change, which contributed to the worst forest fire season in three decades.


So far, the summer of 2025 has been 2.1°C hotter than the average from 1991 to 2020 and exceeded the previous record, set in 2022, by 0.1°C, the agency said.
Nine of the 10 hottest summers in Spain occurred in the 21st century - and the future scenario is also likely to be hot. "These summers of 2022 and 2025 are a trailer - or spoiler - for what could happen in the middle of the century," said AEMET spokesman Ruben del Campo. "One out of every three days this summer we've been under a heat wave."
Del Campo also said that Spain will need to adopt measures to adapt to the heat, while at the same time contributing to the global effort to curb climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
The country experienced three heatwaves lasting 36 days last summer. One of them, lasting 16 days in August, caused temperatures to exceed 45°C in southern Spain and was the most intense ever recorded, according to AEMET.
The intense heat helped fuel forest fires that burned a record 1.03 million hectares across the European Union, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System.
Countries around the world have been experiencing record heat in recent years as global warming intensifies. The summer of 2024 was the hottest in the northern hemisphere, while this year was the hottest in Britain since records began in 1884. Last year as a whole was also the hottest on record.

urn:contentItem:6GRN-SV73-RXRC-J0TG-00000-00Three forest fires reported in Cundinamarca: Firefighters work to control the emergency2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisThree forest fires reported in Cundinamarca: Firefighters work to control the emergency


The Cundinamarca Fire Department is attending this Saturday three forest fires in the municipalities of Ricaurte, Nilo and Sasaima. Although no injuries, fatalities or damage to homes have been reported, the relief agencies are working to control and liquidate the emergencies.


READ ALSO

In the municipality of Ricaurte, a forest fire was reported in the El Paso sector. Currently, it is 98 percent controlled and firefighters continue to carry out constant monitoring of hot spots while extinguishing and liquidation activities are reactivated. So far, no injuries or fatalities have been reported at the site.Around 9 p.m. last night, the governor of Cundinamarca, Jorge Emilio Rey, had informed that the Municipal Council of Disaster Risk Management Cmgrd activated the Unified Command Post to coordinate the attention."The firefighters of Tocaima and Agua De Dios are working together to control the emergency and prevent the spread of the flames," said the president, who said that there is still no consolidated figure of hectares affected.Meanwhile, in the municipality of Nilo, specifically in the village of Los Curos sector Las Flores, there was a forest fire that ended up affecting approximately 15 hectares. In the last report of the relief agencies, the fire was 70 percent controlled, according to the Cundinamarca Fire Department, native forest was affected and fauna was displaced. No injuries, fatalities or damage to houses were reported. According to the Risk Management Unit of Cundinamarca, the emergency is being attended by 10 units of firefighters who have been on site since the morning hours to liquidate the emergency.Finally, authorities reported another forest fire in the municipality of Sasaima, in the limits of the Pilaca and Lanillo villages. The last known report indicated that it was 85 percent controlled thanks to the attention of the municipality's firefighters.
READ ALSO

Other emergencies in CundinamarcaOn the other hand, the Risk Management Unit of Cundinamarca reports other natural events that are being monitored in Guayabetal, where there is still a risk at the Los Canes bridge due to the rising of the Blanco river. According to the agencies, the banks are affected, with the risk of affecting the road that connects six villages: Tunque, Naranjal, Gázquez, La Palma, Conucos and San Marcos. The Instituto de Caminos y Construcciones de Cundinamarca lccu has already transferred a caterpillar machine to the area... On the other hand, in Quetame: active mass movements continue in several tertiary road corridors, with loss of road and access to the urban area in the El Algodonal sector. In Chipaque, on the road to El Llano, the Bogotá - Villavicencio national corridor is still affected, specifically at kilometer 18+600 with total closure. Currently, the road concessionaire Coviandina is working with the support of Iccu in the habilitation of 680 meters of a variant of the old road to give progressive passage to private, cargo and passenger vehicles as of this Monday.With the mass removal process, three houses were affected and there are 10 under monitoring.NICOLÁS DÍAZ MALPICARedacción Bogotá

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y5M3-RRRC-619M-00000-00Santa Cruz declares red alert for forest fires2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisSanta Cruz declares red alert for forest fires


As a result of the increase in forest fires and the persistent drought, the Government of Santa Cruz declared this Monday the departmental red alert, in application of Law 602 of Risk Management.


The measure seeks to activate the mechanisms of prevention and response to the critical period of environmental emergencies.
"Due to what Law 602 of Risk Management indicates, today we declare a red alert. We are in a critical period and progressive increase of forest fire emergencies in the department of Santa Cruz", informed Paulo Viruez, Director of Natural Resources of the Government.
The decision was made in view of the progressive increase in forest fire emergencies. Currently there are seven active fires in the department.
The most complicated is registered in Protachuelo. In this municipality, brigades of the Governor's Office, urban firefighters and volunteers are working together with the Ranger regiment of Montero. Fifty-six troops were deployed to control and combat the flames.
In addition, there is a risk of fires in 26 municipalities, according to Viruez.
The official said that it was suggested to the municipal governments to activate the mechanisms to advance in the declarations of emergency or disaster due to drought or forest fires.
He also said that the municipal emergency commands should be activated, in order to have the necessary personnel and resources to deal with emergencies.

urn:contentItem:6GH2-TGV3-RS13-S026-00000-00New Found Gold Announces Temporary Suspension of Heavy Equipment Exploration Activities on the Queensway Gold Project in Response to Forest Fire Risk in the Region2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisNew Found Gold Announces Temporary Suspension of Heavy Equipment Exploration Activities on the Queensway Gold Project in Response to Forest Fire Risk in the RegionVANCOUVER, BC, Aug. 13, 2025

PR NewswireVANCOUVER, BC, Aug. 13, 2025 /PRNewswire/ - New Found Gold Corp. ("New Found Gold" or the "Company") (TSXV: NFG) (NYSE-A: NFGC) announces the temporary suspension of all exploration activities involving heavy equipment in or near forested areas including, drilling, mulching and excavating on the Company's 100% owned Queensway Gold Project ("Queensway" or the "Project"), located in Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada in response to the forest fire risk in the region.

Keith Boyle, Chief Executive Officer, commented: "The Fire Weather index across the island of Newfoundland is classified as Extreme or Very High, with several major fires burning. At this time, our thoughts are with our employees and contractors, our local communities, and the people of Newfoundland and Labrador. On behalf of the entire New Found Gold team, I send our sincere thanks to the firefighters who are working tirelessly to battle the blazes currently burning in the province."The Company expects to provide additional information when available.About New Found Gold Corp.New Found Gold holds a 100% interest in Queensway, located in Newfoundland and Labrador, a Tier 1 jurisdiction with excellent infrastructure and a skilled local workforce.The Company has completed an initial MRE and PEA at Queensway (see New Found Gold news release dated March 24, 2025 and July 21, 2025).Recent drilling continues to yield new discoveries along strike and down dip of known gold zones, pointing to the district-scale potential of the 175,450 ha project that covers a 110 km strike extent along two prospective fault zones.New Found Gold has a new management team in place, a solid shareholder base, which includes a 19% holding by Eric Sprott, and is focused on growth and value creation at Queensway.Keith Boyle, P.Eng.

urn:contentItem:6GS2-BFM3-RRPM-54G9-00000-00Selection posers for Sheehan as Swans prepare to fight Forest fire2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 45Selection posers for Sheehan as Swans prepare to fight Forest fireTOM COLEMAN

SWANSEA City turn their attention to the Carabao Cup tonight and boss Alan Sheehan has a number of decisions to make in almost every position.

Premier League Nottingham Forest are set to roll into town, with new boss Ange Postecoglou looking to get his reign at the City Ground up and running after a chastening 3-0 defeat to title-chasing Arsenal at the weekend.

How seriously he decides to take this competition remains to be seen. On the one hand, he may feel the league and Europe are the more pressing priorities. On the other, he may have identified this as a trophy Forest could potentially win.

Sheehan's approach is also going to be fascinating to see.

The Swans boss made a few changes to his side for the win over Plymouth Argyle in the last round, and may well do the same again this time around, although given the level of opposition, there's clearly a chance he could yet opt for a more or less full strength line-up.

Should Sheehan decide to mix things up, there are a number of players who could come in.

Andy Fisher The second-choice goalkeeper produced a brilliant showing in the previous round. He's still firmly behind Lawrence Vigouroux in the pecking order when it comes to the league, but he's not yet let down his side in this competition. Could well get the nod again here.

Sam Parker The right-back area is one of several positions where Sheehan potentially faces a dilemma. On the one hand, Josh Key might well benefit from the rest. On the other, it could be seen as a gamble to throw the youngster in against such a high standard of opponent. Still, it wouldn't be a surprise to see him involved, although there's a possibility Ethan Galbraith could start there too.

Kaelan Casey Like Fisher, this competition seems his most likely source of minutes at the moment. Did pretty well against Plymouth and you suspect one of Cameron Burgess or Ben Cabango will be rested. Could well start from the off.

Cameron Burgess There's an argument for Cabango here and, if he was fit, Ricardo Santos might well be in the mix for contention too. But given his Premier League experience, it feels more likely the Australian will be called up.

Ishe Samuels-Smith A similar situation to the right-back conundrum. The 19-year-old is highly rated, but largely inexperienced. Were this not against Premier League opposition, he would surely be in from the off, but Sheehan may decide it's too much of a risk. Not just in the context of the night, but also for the player's confidence going forward. That said, his presence on the bench against Hull City on Saturday suggests he's already on the cusp of first-team inclusion. There's also the point that Josh Tymon is surely in need of a break.

Marko Stamenic This is assuming he's fit, of course. The midfielder would clearly love to take on his former club, and his skillset would undoubtedly give Swansea's midfield an extra edge. The New Zealander is likely to be first choice in the league campaign, but could perhaps still do with some more minutes under his belt.

Ethan Galbraith It's difficult not to see how the Northern Irishman wouldn't be involved in some capacity. There's every chance he could be handed a more advanced role, but with Goncalo Franco looking a little bit rusty, and with Sheehan surely likely to implement the double pivot at the base of midfield, we could see him in a similar role to the one we saw on Saturday.

Manuel Benson A lot will depend on where his match fitness is right now. The winger hasn't played an awful lot of football for the past couple of seasons. But if he can prove himself on the training ground, there's every chance we'll see him in a Swans shirt for the first time here. That said, Brazilian Ronald is a man in form, and he will be itching to test himself against a higher calibre of opposition. Liam Cullen Melker Widell started the last round, but the prospect of seeing what Cullen could potentially do in the deeper role behind the 9 could prove tempting. The Wales international is seen as a hugely important figure in this squad, but his place in the side no longer feels as concrete as before given the level of competition in the squad now. This could be a good chance to shine.

Eom Jisung Feels like a potential toss-up between the Korean and Zeidane Inoussa. It's possible Malick Yalcouye might be considered there, although it's understood Sheehan doesn't really view the Brighton and Hove Albion loanee as a winger. Another key decision awaits.

Adam Idah Came off the bench for his debut, but it seems a decent bet he'll be handed a bigger role here. Like Ronald, Zan Vipotnik is a man in form, and may well feel he's done enough to earn a start against Premier League opposition.

>Alan Sheehan

urn:contentItem:6H46-BRS3-RV3V-N322-00000-00Studies from School of Humanities and Social Sciences Add New Findings in the Area of Sustainability Research (Forest Carbon Buffers and Sustainability-linked Price Premiums: Advancing Climate Resilience In Uttarakhand's Himalayan Forests)2025-11-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisSUSTAINABILITY RESEARCHStudies from School of Humanities and Social Sciences Add New Findings in the Area of Sustainability Research (Forest Carbon Buffers and Sustainability-linked Price Premiums: Advancing Climate Resilience In Uttarakhand's Himalayan Forests)


2025 NOV 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Economics Daily Report -- Research findings on Sustainability Research are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Uttar Pradesh, India, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Climate change is escalating forest fire risks, threatening the durability of forest-based carbon offsets and undermining long-term climate mitigation efforts. Voluntary Carbon Market (VCM) projects commonly establish buffer pools to safeguard against carbon loss, with buyers offering price premiums for credits that include such provisions."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the School of Humanities and Social Sciences, "However, forest-dependent communities often lack adequate financial incentives to maintain large buffer areas, which limits participation in these programs. This study examines whether ecosystem services provided by buffer forests, particularly hydrological benefits, can be incorporated into sustainability-linked carbon price premiums to encourage larger buffers and reduce fire exposure. Using a bioeconomic optimization model calibrated for Uttarakhand, India, we analyze how communities allocate land between oak forests and agriculture while managing fuelwood harvesting. The model accounts for income from carbon sequestration and payments for water-based ecosystem services (PES), and it endogenizes fire risk as a function of forest species composition, which is shaped by harvesting and buffer management. Buffer zones and species composition also affect groundwater recharge and streamflow, thereby influencing PES revenues. Results show that carbon premiums tied to buffer size enhance conservation outcomes by promoting reduced harvesting, expanding buffer areas, and lowering fire risks. When high-intensity fires are anticipated, communities tend to allocate more land to buffers as insurance against carbon leakage. However, in high-risk contexts, a resource discounting effect may suppress buffer investments unless additional PES incentives, particularly those linked to downstream water benefits, are provided."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These findings highlight the importance of integrating carbon and water-based payments into sustainability-linked price premiums that reflect multiple ecosystem services, thereby enhancing buffer effectiveness, strengthening project integrity, and promoting long-term community engagement in forest conservation."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Forest Carbon Buffers and Sustainability-linked Price Premiums: Advancing Climate Resilience In Uttarakhand's Himalayan Forests. Land Use Policy, 2025;158. urn:contentItem:6H46-BRN3-RV3V-N081-00000-00Studies from South China Agricultural University Describe New Findings in Machine Learning (Machine-learning-assisted Joint Optimization of Impeller and Volute for 6 Mf-20 Centrifugal Fire Extinguishers With Three-dimension Computational Fluid ...)2025-11-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGStudies from South China Agricultural University Describe New Findings in Machine Learning (Machine-learning-assisted Joint Optimization of Impeller and Volute for 6 Mf-20 Centrifugal Fire Extinguishers With Three-dimension Computational Fluid ...)


2025 NOV 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Fresh data on Machine Learning are presented in a new report. According to news originating from Guangzhou, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Centrifugal fire extinguishers are crucial for forest fire prevention. However, traditional design and optimization methods are often hindered by the high dimensionality of design variables."


Financial supporters for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC), National Natural Science Foundation of Guangdong Province, Basic and Applied Basic Research Special Project in Guangzhou, China, Specific university discipline construction project, China, Open Research Subject of Key Laboratory of Fluid and Power Machinery (Xihua University) , Ministry of Education, China.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from South China Agricultural University, "This study introduces a novel three-dimensional modeling and impeller-volute joint optimization strategy for the 6 MF-20 centrifugal fire extinguisher, employing Machine Learning (ML) and Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to overcome these limitations. We propose an AI-assisted framework, integrating a Back-Propagation Artificial Neural Network (BPANN) with the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II), aimed at enhancing flow rate and efficiency. The framework is trained on a high-precision CFD dataset, enabling it to capture complex nonlinear relationships between design parameters and extinguisher performance. Hyper-parameters of the learning model are optimized using Bayesian Optimization algorithms. Comparative experiments compare the optimized impeller against the original counterpart. Numerical outcomes indicate that the optimization of 8 design parameters results in a 19.18 % increase in flow rate and an 18.76 % enhancement in efficiency within the impeller-volute joint optimization. Experimental performance enhancement of the optimized impellers is confirmed at 10.68 %. The standard deviations of the experimental data for the optimized impeller are approximately 0.003 and 0.007, significantly lower than those of the prototype impeller."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This research underscores the significant potential of AI in the optimization of mechanical systems, with determination coefficients R2 for BPANN exceeding 0.95, indicating high model accuracy and reliability."
For more information on this research see: Machine-learning-assisted Joint Optimization of Impeller and Volute for 6 Mf-20 Centrifugal Fire Extinguishers With Three-dimension Computational Fluid Dynamics and Experiment. Case Studies in Thermal Engineering, 2025;75. Case Studies in Thermal Engineering can be contacted at: Elsevier, Radarweg 29, 1043 Nx Amsterdam, Netherlands.
The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from Biyi Cheng, South China Agricultural University, College of Engineering, Guangzhou 510642, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Xinde Zhang, Leya Lao, Baihao Chen, Nuo Xu, Hongjun Wang and Zhibo Lu.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.csite.2025.107140. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-MF03-RRR2-82T6-00000-00Forest fire and hire2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 28Forest fire and hireMarinakis sacks Nuno and appoints Postecoglou as his replacement in an intense 24 hoursDave Filmer

NOTTINGHAM Forest did not waste any time replacing Nuno Espirito Santo yesterday as they immediately installed Ange Postecoglou as their new manager.

The writing was on the wall for Nuno when his relationship with owner Evangelos Marinakis broke down despite steering Forest towards European football.

He was axed late on Monday and it was quickly evident yesterday morning that former Tottenham boss Postecoglou was in line to fill the void.

The Australian - who has agreed a two-year deal - was sacked by Spurs in June, 16 days after winning the Europa League as he paid the price for dismal domestic form. It is that knack for landing silverware however, winning Spurs' first in 17 years, which convinced Marinakis the ex-Celtic chief is the man he wants.

The Greek tycoon said: 'We are bringing a coach to the club who has a proven and consistent record of winning trophies.

'His experience of coaching teams at the highest level, along with his desire to build something special with us at Forest, makes him a fantastic person to help us on our journey and achieve consistently all our ambitions.

'After gaining promotion to the Premier League, then building consistently season after season to secure European football, we now must take the right step to compete with the very best and challenge for trophies. Ange has the credentials and the track record to do this.'

Postecoglou is charged with getting the best from a squad bolstered over the summer by the likes of Dan Ndoye, James McAtee, Omari Hutchinson and Igor Jesus. His first challenge will be a trip back to north London to take on Arsenal on Saturday, the first of four straight away games.

The 60-year-old will demand better than fans saw in Nuno's final match in charge - a 3-0 home defeat to West Ham.

That result did not help the relationship between owner and manager, with the pair having publicly fallen out over the summer. Cracks had appeared last season, despite a seventh-placed finish and that first European qualification since 1995, with Nuno and global head of football Edu not seeing eye to eye.

Nuno questioned the club's transfer business ahead of the new season and then pre-empted his own sacking by saying 'where there's smoke, there's fire' when asked about his future at the club.

Marinakis pulled the plug on planned peace talks and Nuno was axed 'following recent circumstances', said the club.

Forest thanked him for 'his contribution during a very successful era at the City Ground, in particular his role in the 202425 season, which will forever be remembered fondly in the history of the club'.

Bold-thinking owner right to trust his instinct page 27 ?

Strained relations: But Marinakis (above left) will hope to put issues with Nuno (top left) behind him after appointing Postecoglou

urn:contentItem:6GRN-SV33-RXJ5-821P-00000-00Fire in Quito, in San Juan, is reactivated2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisFire in Quito, in San Juan, is reactivated


The forest fire that started on Friday, September 13, 2025 was reactivated this Sunday morning, September 14.
The Fire Department confirmed operations after coordination with ECU 911. The presence of smoke in the area alerted the teams.
The smoke is visible from the north-central area of the city of Quito.
Fire situation in Quito
The emergency occurs in the San Juan protection zone. It is located in the northwest of Quito.


This Saturday afternoon, September 13, 2025, the Quito Fire Department confirmed that the fire was under control.
However, this Sunday 14, weather conditions changed. The agency reported that the fire was reactivated by strong winds, in a publication of the institution in social networks.
The priority is focused on controlling the active front with logistic units and ground brigades. Control tasks are complicated in such sectors due to topographic conditions.
Background of the fire in Quito
The Quito Fire Department reported on Saturday 13, at 15:03, attended a waste burning. An hour later there was an update. It was confirmed that it was a forest fire.
To deal with the emergency, ground brigades and a helicopter were deployed to discharge water in areas of difficult access. Around 130 personnel worked on the ground.
At the same time, the teams must establish containment lines and carry out patrols to identify secondary sources.
Effects of smoke in the city
Smoke from a fire can affect citizens. If to this is added the presence of strong winds, such as those recorded this Sunday, the spread can be greater.
If you are located near the area or if the smoke has spread, it is recommended to close windows and avoid intense physical activity.
Fines for fires in Quito
Firefighters recalled that causing forest fires involves an economic penalty and imprisonment. The fine can be up to US$ 35,000.
The institution has also urged to report those who cause fires in the city.

urn:contentItem:6GP6-0J33-RVGC-41MH-00000-00The fire in Carballeda de Valdeorras (Ourense) is still active after burning more than 500 hectares.2025-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisThe fire in Carballeda de Valdeorras (Ourense) is still active after burning more than 500 hectares.


A forest fire remains active in the parish of Casaio, located in Carballeda de Valdeorras(Ourense), since Saturday afternoon. According to initial estimates of the Consellería do Medio Rural, the fire has already devastated more than 500 hectares.


The intense gusts of wind are considerably complicating the extinguishing tasks, after the fire was declared at 14:56 hours the previous day. Testimonies of neighbors indicate that the origin of the fire is located on the old wolfram mine of Valborraz. In addition, during the early hours of the morning, the flames spread and even endangered the village.
To fight the fire, three technicians, eighteen agents, twenty-two brigades, twenty-one motor-pumps, four shovels, three technical support units, six helicopters and four airplanes have been deployed.
The parish of Casaio was already the scene of another large fire in August, when 5,300 hectares burned in the Trevincamountains area, according to data from the Xunta. On that occasion, the fire originated in Porto, in the Zamoran region of Sanabria, and crossed the border to Ourense.
On this occasion, according to sources of Rural Environment, the fire does not come from the neighboring province, but has started in Ourense territory.

urn:contentItem:6GP6-0J33-RV94-V44N-00000-00Firefighters explain two factors that reduced forest fires in Quito2025-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisFirefighters explain two factors that reduced forest fires in Quito


In 2024, Quito experienced one of the most severe forest fire seasons in recent years. The Quito Chamber of Commerce estimated economic losses of US$20 million.


The Fire Department stated that 99% of the fires were caused by human action, mainly agricultural burning, garbage burning and campfires on excursions.
Decrease in forest fires in Quito
Between July and November 2024, 340 forest fires were reported, destroying 2,274 hectares of vegetation.
From July 1 to September 1, 2025, the Metropolitan District of Quito recorded 15 forest fires that affected 131.65 hectares. During the same period, 615 waste burnings were recorded, affecting 11.26 hectares.
Captain Diana Villacrés, head of the Forest Fire Brigade, said that "within the statistics we have had a downward trend".
These activities were developed in schools, colleges, universities, rural parishes and neighborhoods considered vulnerable after the 2024 fires.
Captain Villacrés indicated that the weather is another factor. The rains kept the vegetation moist and reduced the risk of fires.
Inamhi reported that in the Sierra, which includes Quito, rainfall in July and August 2025 was within normal, although in some sectors it was below average. In 2024 it rained almost nothing, he explains.
For September, a slight rebound is expected, with values around or a little below what was expected.
Control actions implemented in Quito
The Fire Department maintains temporary forestry brigades in risk sectors.
In coordination with the Metropolitan Control Agency, daily patrols are carried out to sanction those who cause fires or burns.

urn:contentItem:6GS9-D2P3-RT5V-H4HD-00000-00Swans douse the Forest fire with a stunning late comeback win2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 46,47Swans douse the Forest fire with a stunning late comeback winTOM COLEMAN

SWANSEA 3 CITY Cameron Burgess 68, 90 (+7) Zan Vipotnik 90 (+3)

NOTTINGHAM 2 FOREST

Igor Jesus 15, 45 (+1) SWANSEA City are into the fourth round of the Carabao Cup for the first time in eight seasons, after they fought back from two goals down to claim a dramatic late win over Nottingham Forest, who are still looking for their first win under Ange Postecoglou.

Much had been made of the Australian's presence in the visiting dugout here, in what were atrocious conditions at a sodden www.Swansea.com Stadium, but stoppage-time goals from Zan Vipotnik and Cameron Burgess, who had previously headed home to give the hosts an unlikely lifeline, were enough to seal an incredible victory.

It had initially looked as though Forest's Premier League quality would shine through here, with Igor Jesus netting from a tight angle after 15 minutes, before popping up with a well-worked second on the stroke of half-time.

Swansea may well feel they should have had a penalty shortly before that second goal, after Malick Yalcouye was bundled over inside the box by Willy Boly, but his appeals fell on deaf ears.

Burgess then headed home midway inside the second half to give the hosts hope, before Vipotnik turned home in the 93rd minute to restore parity.

Then, with more or less the last kick of the game, Burgess fired home after Ethan Galbraith's effort had come back off the woodwork.

It's Swansea's first cup win over Premier League opposition since 2014, having previously lost all of their last nine attempts, and this sensational result also extends an astonishing unbeaten home record under Alan Sheehan, which stretches back to March.

As well as the fight, the grit, and the spirit, there were individual positives all over the pitch for Sheehan, who made six changes for this clash.

Among them were full debut's for deadline day signings Adam Idah, Manuel Benson, and Ishe SamuelsSmith, the latter marking his first outing in senior football with a reasonably assured performance.

Indeed, Swansea also started this contest firmly on the front foot.

Eom Jisung had an effort deflected wide inside eight minutes after pinching the ball deep inside the Forest half.

Galbraith then had a shot blocked from the resulting corner, as Swansea's intensity out of possession visibly unsettled their more glamorous opponents.

However, and arguably against the run of play, it was Forest who would strike first blood.

Omari Hutchinsion's low cross was deflected into the path of Jesus, who produced a smart finish from a tight angle to slide the ball beyond Andy Fisher and into the net.

A sucker punch for the Swans, but to their credit they kept going. Eom hit a low drive just wide after 20 minutes, while Benson sent a freekick well over about five minutes later.

Swansea then felt they should have had a penalty, but Yalcouye's appeals were waved away after he was sent sprawling in the box by Boly. Replays suggested he probably had a strong case.

Forest nearly compounded those frustrations just moments later as McAtee steered wide at the other end, but Forest wouldn't have to wait too long to double their lead.

An admittedly impressive move saw the City defence carved open, with McAtee getting behind the back line before sending a low cross in for Hutchinson at the far post, and his tap across goal found Jesus, who was left with a simple finish.

Jesus was given the second half off as the two teams emerged from the tunnel, although Forest still looked a threat. Ryan Yates had an effort blocked, while McAtee fired over following a neat one-two inside the box. Arnaud Kalimuendo then had the ball in the net, but was denied by the offside flag.

Sheehan responded after the hour by making a triple substitution, but Swansea's hopes of getting back into the contest looked to be fading.

That all changed 22 minutes from time as Eom's corner was headed home brilliantly by Burgess.

But their joy might well have been cut short just two minutes later were it not for the palm of Fisher, who was down well to deny Callum HudsonOdoi's low effort.

Vipotnik was introduced off the bench as Sheehan intensified his efforts to chase the game, but Forest kept asking questions.

Yates hooked over from a corner, then saw a scuffed effort cleared off the line by Casey, before Kalimuendo fired into the side-netting with 10 minutes to go.

Hudson-Odoi then fired wide from close range as Swansea continued to weather the storm.

And, ncredibly, their efforts were rewarded deep into stoppage time as Vipotnik turned home Liam Cullen's low cross to score his fifth goal of the season, sparking bedlam amongst the home faithful.

Penalties beckoned, but the Jack Army's euphoria was sent into the stratosphere moments later.

Galbraith clanged an effort off the post from distance, and Burgess, somehow, popped up and thrashed home the rebound to sensationally send Swansea into the last 16. Swansea City: Fisher; Key, Burgess, Casey, Samuels-Smith (Tymon 64); Galbraith, Franco (Widell 64); Benson (Ronald 64), Yalcouye (Cullen 85), Eom; Idah (Vipotnik 79) Subs: Farman, Cabango, Wales, Inoussa Nottingham Forest: Victor; Savona, Boly, Morato (Kalimuendo 46), Zinchenko; Yates, Douglas Luiz (Hudson-Odoi 62), Bakwa (GibbsWhite 62), McAtee (Sangare 84), Hutchinson, Igor Jesus (Cunha 46) Subs: Gunn, Awoniyi, Ndoye, Abbott Referee: John Busby

Cameron Burgess celebrates Swansea's last-gasp winnerNottingham Forest's Omari Hutchinson holds off Swansea's Josh Key PICTURES: Huw Evans Agency

urn:contentItem:6GY1-23T3-S2D1-G2R3-00000-00Rep. Moses sponsors bill to aid development of soybean-based fire suppressants2025-10-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSRep. Moses sponsors bill to aid development of soybean-based fire suppressantsChris VetterThe Leader-Telegram, Eau Claire, Wis.

MENOMONIE — As tariffs have led to China not purchasing U.S.-grown soybeans this year, state Rep. Clint Moses (R-Menomonie) has introduced legislation to assist in a new use for the crop.

Soybeans can be used to make a ‘soy foam’ that is free of PFAS “forever chemicals” that would be used in firefighting.

“We have a big production of soybeans, and it’s a great new avenue to market them,” Moses told the Leader-Telegram.

The bill would allow products derived from soybeans and used as fire suppressant to be purchased under a Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources forest fire suppression grant program. The bill would let fire departments use grant funds to cover up to 50% of the cost of soybean-derived fire suppressants, in addition to fire-resistant clothing and equipment.

Moses noted the measure is backed by the Wisconsin Soybean Association, and he said the PFAS-free foam is a benefit to firefighters, farmers and the environment.

“I look at it as more than a pilot program,” Moses said. “I hope it has statewide support.”

Moses headed to Madison on Tuesday to caucus with other Republicans and he said he would be circulating the bill and getting more support for it.

“I assume the legislators from my part of the state will sign on,” Moses said.

Moses noted that it appears farmers will have an early harvest and a large crop this year, but he added that tariffs are impacting them this year.

U.S. farmers grew $60.7 billion worth of soybeans, or nearly 4.3 billion bushels, in the 2022-2023 marketing year, according to the American Soybean Association. Just over half were exported.

In past years, China has purchased about $12 billion worth of U.S. soybeans. However, that country has put a 20% retaliatory tariff on U.S. soybeans, and thus, has not purchased any this year.

President Donald Trump is reportedly exploring a possible measure to assist farmers due to the loss of the export market.

The forest fire suppression grant program dollars are available to cities, villages, towns, counties and fire suppression organizations that enter into a written agreement to assist DNR in the suppression of forest fires when requested, according to a follow-up statement from Moses’ office. A total of $448,000 in forestry grants are available for these grants in each year of the 2025-27 biennium, which may be supplemented by federal funds received through the DNR.

Traditional firefighting foams have contained PFAS chemicals that not only persist in the environment but have been linked to an increased cancer risks for firefighters. The Firefighter Cancer Support Network reports that firefighters nationwide have a 68% higher chance of getting cancer than the average person.

In 2020, the DNR banned the use of PFAS-based firefighting foams, the data from Moses’ office states. But fire departments have struggled to find suitable replacements due to the effectiveness of the foams at putting out severe liquid fuel fires. Ten fire departments in Wisconsin currently use soy foam. This foam is not only an excellent Class A wetting agent and fire retardant for controlled burns, but is also an effective Class B firefighting foam used to put out fuel fires and provide vapor suppression. However, many fire departments are not able to purchase the product because state statute doesn’t allow products derived from soybean to be purchased under the grant program they utilize.

Chippewa Valley Technical College does research to find alternatives to PFAS-based fire suppressant materials. Cross Plains Solutions has developed a fire suppressant that uses soybeans as the main ingredient. Soybean flour is a main ingredient for a fire suppressant. Cross Plains Solutions has developed the fire suppressant from soybeans that is deemed PFAS-free and environmentally friendly.
