urn:contentItem:6GYP-6813-RS18-63XS-00000-00Forest fire, forest future Historical play explores how the Yacolt Burn changed lives and fortunes in north Clark County2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisLIFEPg. B1Forest fire, forest future Historical play explores how the Yacolt Burn changed lives and fortunes in north Clark CountyScott Hewitt The Columbian

Hiram Garner (Michael Reid of Vancouver) aims his shotgun to break up a romantic moment between his daughter, Essie (Laura Henderson of Vancouver), and Weyerhaeuser land agent Jamie (Cody Swires of Longview).

Bobby Pallotta/Love Street Playhouse

Photos by Bobby Pallotta/Love Street Playhouse

The Yacolt Burn of 1902 roars toward the Garner homestead in Yacolt in David Bareford's new play "There's Still Snow on Silver Star." Left to right are Michael Reid as Hiram, Katie Norcross as Kit, Laura Henderson as Essie and Cody Swires as Jamie.

Bobby Pallotta/Love Street Playhouse

Essie Garner (Laura Henderson) and Jamie Walsh (Cody Swires) attempt to fight off the Yacolt Burn and save the Garner homestead in David Bareford's play "There's Still Snow on Silver Star."

Bobby Pallotta/Love Street Playhouse

Best friends Essie (Laura Henderson, center) and Kit (Katie Norcross) share a laugh as Weyerhaeuser agent Jamie (Cody Swires) contemplates a scheme to procure local land.

The Columbian files

The 1902 Yacolt Burn, which killed 38 people and burned 239,000 acres in three counties, came right to the edge of Yacolt, then changed directions. This Weyerhaeuser Company photo of Yacolt was taken circa 1903.

The Jenny Creek Fire of summer 2023 got within about a mile of playwright David Bareford's home in north Clark County, and his family prepared to evacuate.
"You're faced with the question of, what do we take? What's important? It makes you reassess all your priorities," Bareford said. "It's a fascinating feeling. There is no right answer."


Bareford never had to evacuate, fortunately, but the characters in his new historical play face similar questions and hard choices as they confront crop failure, debt, heartbreak and, ultimately, the massive Yacolt Burn forest fire of September 1902.
Woodland's Love Street Playhouse is staging performances of Bareford's "There's Still Snow on Silver Star" from Sept. 12 to Oct. 5.
Bareford, who relocated from Chicago to the Woodland area in 2012, loves exploring what he calls "the margins of history" in his plays. "There's Still Snow on Silver Star" was inspired by his amazement at learning about the Yacolt Burn, a historic blaze that started near Cascade Locks in Oregon, jumped the Columbia River and swept across a big swath of Southwest Washington, including east Clark County. It burned a total of 239,000 acres and killed 38 people.
"Three-hundred-foot-high flames moving at 30 miles per hour," Bareford said. "What can you do in the face of that?"
Even before fire arrives in "There's Still Snow on Silver Star," change is already in the air in 1902 north county, personified by Jamie, a smooth, attractive and merciless agent for land baron Frederick Weyerhaeuser. Jamie's job is driving hard bargains as he snaps up humble homesteads and flips them to loggers and lumber mills, and he finds an easy victim in Hiram Garner, a hapless potato farmer and widower who's so ornery, he refuses to apply the newcomer name "Yacolt" to the patch of ground he homesteaded first. Garner's potato crop is blighted and his investment in a Lewis River steamboat that burned and sank has left him in debt.
The only person more ornery than Hiram is his bright, educated, unmarried daughter, Essie, who seems to fear the future even more than he does.
"Progress? Electricity?" Essie says. "Not all things we can invent are for the good. Risk burning down your house every time you turn a switch. I don't like electricity   because it hides in the walls and pretends to be friendly, until it decides it isn't and it kills you."
It doesn't take Essie long to sniff out exactly what Jamie is: the sort of schemer who could sell water to a fish, according to Bareford's script. She also senses an opportunity. But at what cost to her own heart?
Personal values, and the value of timberland before and after it has burned, shift like the hot wind in "There's Still Snow on Silver Star."
"You learn somethin' spendin' the night standin' in a crick, water up to your waist, breathin' smoke, watchin' the orange glow of Hell itself fillin' the sky," says Essie's friend Kit. "Stood there all night, two dozen other folk all huddled around."
Such details are drawn directly from Bareford's research about the Yacolt Burn, he said.
Some people buried themselves in sand or sheltered in nearby creeks to escape the fire, he said.
Horrific as it was, Bareford said, the fire also kickstarted a salvage logging industry that transformed the town of Yacolt - which, amazingly, was only singed by the fire before it changed directions - into a temporary boomtown of 10,000.
"This is when Weyerhaeuser changed from real estate speculator   and got into the timber and logging businesses," Bareford said.
Limbs, branches and outermost tree layers were gone, but plenty of good wood still lurked inside, and there was big money to be made retrieving it. The following month, a record-setting 13.6 million board feet of timber was produced in the region.
"Even though the fire has come through and it looks like we are all burned up," Bareford summed up, "we can still have strength, and beauty, and maybe even love."
Special effects
Bareford is a longtime thespian, playwright and director with a specialty in theatrical violence design - that is, choreographing onstage combat that looks dangerously real, but isn't.
There's no hand-to-hand combat in "There's Still Snow on Silver Star," but its characters do battle that massive offstage fire. Bareford said making the fight feel real requires a mix of special-effects techniques, including intense lights and sounds as well as "theatrical haze" and what's called "smoke cloth," a treated fabric that doesn't burn but visibly smolders. (Smoke cloth is usually what you'll see putting off fake smoke from a theatrical cigarette in an ashtray, he said.)
The title "There's Still Snow on Silver Star" is a piece of local folk wisdom that Bareford picked up and repeated to his daughter: Don't move greenhouse plants into the ground if you can still see snow on Silver Star Mountain. Wait until the snow has cleared before planting. Bareford's daughter thought the phrase was the perfect title for a historical romance story, he said, and she was right.
"I like writing local plays for local theaters," Bareford said. "People will resonate with the local names and the history. I like showing our community to itself."
Scott Hewitt: 360-735-4525; scott.hewitt@columbian.com
IF YOU GO
What: "There's Still Snow on Silver Star," written and directed by David Bareford
When: Sept. 12-Oct. 5
Where: Love Street Playhouse, 126 Loves Ave., Woodland
Tickets and information: https://lovestreetplayhouse.com/

urn:contentItem:6GKM-TRP3-RS10-P55G-00000-00Popular beach locked down for second weekend after forest fire2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisUK & WORLD NEWSVersion:1Popular beach locked down for second weekend after forest fireBy, Andrew Forgrave & Olivia Williams

A two-day fire broke out in adjacent woodland

A popular beach was cordoned off for the second weekend in a row after a fire erupted in the neighbouring woodland. Visitors already at the site were asked to give firefighters "space to work" as they battled the blaze.

People said they could smell smoke from the fire in Newborough Forest, which borders Traeth Llanddwyn beach. Illegal wild campers are suspected to be the culprits, and site manager Natural Resources Wales NRW condemned their "irresponsible behaviour".

The local community has been on tenterhooks this summer due to the risk of a major fire caused by tinder-dry conditions. Extra patrols were deployed over the bank holiday weekend, but warnings not to light BBQs and campfires were ignored.

On Sunday evening, August 24, local NRW wardens closed the road gates at Newborough Forest, the route visitors must take to reach the beach. They reported that a small fire in the forest had been put out but was at risk of reigniting.

The wardens stated that they closed the site as a precautionary measure to protect visitors and the local community. The closure was extended through most of Bank Holiday Monday when it was discovered that the fire had reignited, reports North Wales Live.

Just eight days prior, the National Nature Reserve was shut down for the first time ever following reports that wardens had been "overwhelmed" by the number of illegal campers.

Despite the lockdown on Sunday, visitors reportedly flouted the rules and made their way to the beach after parking on the A4080. Numerous cars in the vicinity were slapped with tickets by Anglesey Council enforcement officers.

It wasn't until 9.23pm last night that NRW declared the reserve back open. Visitors were reminded that camping is not permitted and that BBQs are banned in all parts of the reserve.

A spokesperson stated: "The vast majority of people visiting this special place do so responsibly. Yet, this weekend, we have unfortunately seen the significant impact irresponsible behaviour can have on this landscape.

"A single spark from a BBQ or campfire can lead to fires that can devastate habitats and wildlife, and put people at risk of harm. We all have a role to play in minimising the risks of wildfires during this very dry spell. We're asking everyone to follow the rules and help protect what makes this place so special."

Traeth Llandwyn and Newborough Forest have gained popularity on social media, with the beach earning recognition as a filming location for HBO's House of the Dragon series. Despite extensive messaging by NRW, issues have escalated at the reserve this summer.

To address traffic problems in the neighbouring village of Newborough, fresh parking regulations were brought in this summer at Traeth Llandwyn's three car parks.

When at capacity - frequently by 10am during peak periods - these are now shut until mid-afternoon.

All-day fees were also increased to £15.

Yet locals say that latecomers simply park on surrounding streets and undertake the lengthy trek through the woodland to Traeth Llanddwyn.

One person said: "I see hundreds walking past my home on hot days. About 60% are carrying tents, BBQs and back packs. Its heart-breaking."

Wardens can only request visitors to remove tents and put out fires - frequently facing hostility when doing so.

NRW hopes a new barrier-free parking system set to be launched this autumn will help manage overnight camping.

Some people remain doubtful and want more overnight closures.

One woman said online: "Maybe we can sleep a bit better in the evenings knowing that the forest won't go up in flames."

Another agreed there was a need for ongoing patrols.

She said: "Like many other Anglesey residents, I feel unable to enjoy this beautiful place because of the actions of disrespectful people."

urn:contentItem:6H3H-XMD3-RTH7-C0XH-00000-00UNION MINISTRY OF ENVIRONMENT, FOREST AND CLIMATE CHANGE SUCCESSFULLY CONCLUDES SWACHHATA SPECIAL CAMPAIGN 5.02025-10-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisUNION MINISTRY OF ENVIRONMENT, FOREST AND CLIMATE CHANGE SUCCESSFULLY CONCLUDES SWACHHATA SPECIAL CAMPAIGN 5.0States News ServiceNEW DELHI, India

The following information was released by the Government of India:

Revenue Generation of Rs. 41,73,348 along with freeing up of 28,074 square feet of space due to Disposal of Scrap including e-waste; 9,996 physical files weeded out, 4897 e-files closed during the Campaign

Posted On: 31 OCT 2025 6:08PM by PIB Delhi

The Special Campaign on Swachhata was initiated in 2021 at the behest of the Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances (DARPG), Government of India. It is an ongoing exercise for not only promoting cleanliness in Government offices but also to reduce pendency, while giving a boost to ease of business along with citizen welfare. This year Special Campaign 5.0 commenced with the commitment to achieve the key objectives of institutionalizing Swachhata and minimizing pendency. Special emphasis was laid on e-waste and National Plastic Pollution Reduction Campaign (NPPRC).

The Preparatory Phase of the Campaign was held from 15th September to 30th September, 2025. The Implementation Phase was initiated from 2nd October, which ended today on 31st October, 2025. The Special Campaign 5.0 was implemented in all the 132 identified sites of the Ministry and its Subordinate Offices and Autonomous Bodies.

The Union Minister, Environment, Forest and Climate Change (HMEFCC), Shri Bhupender Yadav held meetings, reviewed the implementation of Special Campaign and visited various Divisions/Sections including Record Room at Indira Paryavaran Bhavan, Jor Bagh, New Delhi. Under directions received from HMEFCC, Secretary (MoEFCC), Shri Tanmay Kumar, was regularly monitoring the activities under Special Campaign 5.0 to ensure effective implementation of Swachhta and minimizing pendency.

As regards the achievements under various parameters of Special Campaign 5.0, 100% achievements have been accomplished under Cleanliness Campaign of 132 identified sites, State Government References, Public Grievances, Public Grievance Appeals, review of Physical Files and e-files. A total of 9,996 physical files were weeded out and 4897 e-files were closed. Disposal of scrap including e-waste resulted in revenue generation of Rs. 41,73,348 and 28,074 square feet of space being freed up.

Special Campaign 5.0 at Indira Paryavaran Bhawan, Jor Bagh, New Delhi, Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change.

The prominent Best Practices for plastic reduction and use of eco-friendly material under NPPRC includes the following: -

(i) Zoological Survey of India, Kolkata conducted a clean-up drive in the market place of New Alipore, Kolkata on 2nd October, 2025 through the dedicated ZSI volunteers in a coordinated effort and handed over 450 kg of plastic to the Kolkata Municipal Corporation.

(ii) Indian Council for Forest Research and Education (ICFRE) - Arid Forest Research Institute (AFRI), Jodhpur, Rajasthan developed NAVPRAN (Nutrient-rich, Active, Vital Plantation Regenerative Afforestation Nest) developed as an innovation to replace plastic bags for plantation, as a contribution to environmental cleanliness by ICFRE-AFRI. NAVPRAN is a strong step towards environmental protection by using it in nurseries instead of plastic bags.

(iii) G.B. Pant National Institute of Himalayan Environment, Almora, Uttarakhand installed a Pine processing unit in the Rural Technology Complex (RTC) for making eco-friendly papers, files, folders, carry bags, etc. using Pine needles, which is prone to forest fire. The RTC also uses waste paper from the office to produce new paper, files, folders etc.

(iv) Directorate of Forest Education, Dehradun upcycled 5 unused plastic water tanks into organic waste composters and saved Rs. 2.5 lakh.

urn:contentItem:6G4N-Y503-RSVD-302K-00000-00Data on Machine Learning Reported by Arun Kumar Shukla and Colleagues (Machine learning-based forest fire susceptibility mapping of Southern Mizoram, a part of Indo-Burma Biodiversity Hotspot)2025-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGData on Machine Learning Reported by Arun Kumar Shukla and Colleagues (Machine learning-based forest fire susceptibility mapping of Southern Mizoram, a part of Indo-Burma Biodiversity Hotspot)


2025 JUN 27 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- New research on Machine Learning is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Mandi, India, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires are a significant global environmental hazard, causing widespread economic losses and ecological damage to natural habitats. Biodiversity-rich regions like Mizoram, a northeastern Indian state known for its lush forests and a part of Indo-Burma Biodiversity Hotspot, are particularly vulnerable to these fires."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research, "Between 2012 and 2021, Mizoram incurred losses amounting to approximately $8,910,000 USD due to wildfires. This study addresses the urgent need for high-resolution forest fire susceptibility mapping for southern Mizoram (Lunglei, Lawngtlai, Serchhip, and Tlabung), highlighting the region's ecological fragility and vulnerability. We employed six machine learning (ML) algorithms-AdaBoost, Decision Tree, Gaussian Process, K-Nearest Neighbor, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine and analyzed ten wildfire conditioning factors. These factors include topographical elements (DEM, slope, aspect, curvature, TWI), vegetation indices (pre-fire EVI, pre-fire VARI), anthropogenic factors (LULC), and solar radiation. A forest fire inventory was created using high-resolution satellite images from April 2021 through visual manual interpretation. Feature importance analysis using Gini Impurity revealed that pre-fire NDMI, EVI, DEM, aspect, and solar radiation were the most significant contributors. Performance metrics such as average accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, area under the curve (AUC), and G-mean were used to evaluate the ML algorithms. AUC values ranged from 0.84 to 0.91, with accuracy scores between 0.74 and 0.81. Among the models, the Random Forest algorithm demonstrated the best performance across all metrics. Lawngtlai exhibited the highest susceptibility (64%, 869.66 km), followed by Tlabung (38%, 956.09 km), Lunglei (27%, 556.57 km), and Serchhip (21%, 21.72 km). Overall, 37.01% (2677.21 km) of the study area was classified as highly susceptible. Our analysis further indicates that lower elevations and specific aspect orientations-namely East, Southeast, Southwest, and South-substantially influence forest fire susceptibility. Finally, the forest fire susceptibility map was validated using high-resolution Planet images."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study demonstrates that ML-based susceptibility estimation can be used to implement effective natural resource management and proactive measures to mitigate the environmental impact of forest fires."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Machine learning-based forest fire susceptibility mapping of Southern Mizoram, a part of Indo-Burma Biodiversity Hotspot. Environmental Science and Pollution Research, 2025. Environmental Science and Pollution Research can be contacted at: Springer Heidelberg, Tiergartenstrasse 17, D-69121 Heidelberg, Germany. (Springer - www.springer.com; Environmental Science and Pollution Research - www.springerlink.com/content/0944-1344/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Arun Kumar Shukla, Mandi, India, 175005. Additional authors for this research include Priyanka Gupta and Dericks Praise Shukla.
Publisher contact information for the journal Environmental Science and Pollution Research is: Springer Heidelberg, Tiergartenstrasse 17, D-69121 Heidelberg, Germany.

urn:contentItem:6GSC-5WK3-RTTB-51X3-00000-00DEEP REMINDS RESIDENTS AND VISITORS TO EXERCISE CAUTION DURING FALL WILDFIRE SEASON2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisDEEP REMINDS RESIDENTS AND VISITORS TO EXERCISE CAUTION DURING FALL WILDFIRE SEASONStates News ServiceHARTFORD, CT

The following information was released by the Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection (DEEP):

Being Informed, Aware, and Careful is Critical to Preventing Dangerous Human-caused Wildfires

(HARFORD, CT) The Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection (DEEP) reminds residents and visitors to our state that the typical fall wildfire season in Connecticut runs from October through the first widespread snowfall. During this period, dry weather and windy conditions, in combination with fallen leaves and increased sunlight reaching and warming the forest floor, can elevate the likelihood of a wildfire. Almost all wildfires are caused by humans and are therefore preventable. Maintaining awareness of fire danger and observing appropriate precautions are things that everyone can do to minimize the likelihood of starting a dangerous wildfire.

Connecticut experienced record wildfire activity in fall 2024, with 605 fires burning more than 500 acres, destroying eight structures, and disrupting communities across the state. Governor Ned Lamont declared a state of emergency, issued a statewide burn ban, and activated the Northeast Forest Fire Protection Compact, bringing in support from other states and the National Guard. Hundreds of firefighters and personnel from municipal fire departments, state and federal agencies, and Compact partners dedicated thousands of hours to wildfire response. Eight firefighters were injured during the season, and most tragically, one firefighter, Robert Sharkevich Sr., lost his life in the line of duty.

The statewide emergency last fall was a stark reminder of the dangers wildfires pose in Connecticut, said DEEP Commissioner Katie Dykes. Last year our firefighting capabilities were stretched to the limit, requiring assistance from other states, and Canada. We all share responsibility for preventing wildfires, and in doing so, we help keep our first responders and our neighbors safe. We ask everyone to be extra vigilant this season, by staying informed about the daily fire danger level and local open burning laws, properly attending to outdoor fires at home or when out camping, carefully disposing of home heating ash and smoking materials, and exercising caution with machinery and equipment that could spark near dry grass and leaves.

As we enter the 2025 fall wildfire season and reflect on the historic events of last fall, DEEP reminds residents and visitors to our state of the steps they can take to minimize the likelihood of dangerous wildfires. By being aware and taking appropriate precautions, everyone can play a valuable role in protecting our families, neighbors, and communities.

Stay Informed: Stay up to date on the daily Forest Fire Danger Level and Red Flag warnings. Follow all burn restrictions and local bans. If you have received a permit from your local Open Burning Official to burn on your property, the permit is not valid if the Forest Fire Danger is rated high, very high, or extreme. Keep in mind that wildfires can occur even when fire risk is moderate.

Use Caution with Sparks, Flames, and Combustible Materials:

Prepare Your Home: You can take steps to prepare your home for possible wildfire. Removing vegetation and combustible materials in a 30-foot perimeter around your home creates a wildfire buffer. Learn more from the National Fire Protection Association.

Connecticuts fire risk is increasing as climate change drives more extreme weather patterns, which at times can include drier conditions, hotter temperatures, and stronger winds all of which are risk factors for wildfire. Simultaneously, various forest pests and disease are also increasing the number of dead trees on the Connecticut landscape, further increasing our forests vulnerability to wildfire. Across North America, once-resilient forests are struggling with these compounded pressures, and Connecticuts woodlands are no exception.

DEEP thanks the public for remaining vigilant in protecting our communities, supporting the efforts of our first responders, and safeguarding the states forests for future generations. If you spot a wildfire, remain calm, go to the nearest telephone, and dial 911 to report the fire as quickly as possible to your local fire department. Tell the emergency dispatcher when and where you saw the fire. If you see anything suspicious at or near the scene of the fire, take note and relay that to the dispatcher as well. Stay on the telephone until the dispatcher tells you to hang up.

urn:contentItem:6GFD-R8D3-S23F-516S-00000-00New Remote Sensing Research from University of Missouri Outlined (Deep Learning-Driven Multi-Temporal Detection: Leveraging DeeplabV3+/Efficientnet-B08 Semantic Segmentation for Deforestation and Forest Fire Detection)2025-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGNew Remote Sensing Research from University of Missouri Outlined (Deep Learning-Driven Multi-Temporal Detection: Leveraging DeeplabV3+/Efficientnet-B08 Semantic Segmentation for Deforestation and Forest Fire Detection)


2025 AUG 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on remote sensing. According to news reporting originating from Columbia, Missouri, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Deforestation and forest fires are escalating global threats that require timely, scalable, and cost-effective monitoring systems. While UAV and ground-based solutions offer fine-grained data, they are often constrained by limited spatial coverage, high operational costs, and logistical challenges."


The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from University of Missouri: "In contrast, satellite imagery provides broad, repeatable, and economically feasible coverage. This study presents a deep learning framework that combines the DeepLabV3+ architecture with an EfficientNet-B08 backbone to address both deforestation and wildfire detection using satellite imagery. The system utilizes advanced multi-scale feature extraction and Group Normalization to enable robust semantic segmentation under challenging atmospheric conditions and complex forest structures. It is evaluated on two benchmark datasets. In the Amazon forest segmentation dataset, the model achieves a validation Intersection over Union (IoU) of 0.9100 and a pixel accuracy of 0.9605, demonstrating strong performance in delineating forest boundaries. In FireDataset_20m, which presents a severe class imbalance between fire and non-fire pixels, the framework achieves 99.95% accuracy, 93.16% precision, and 91.47% recall. A qualitative analysis confirms the model's ability to accurately localize fire hotspots and deforested areas."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These results highlight the model's dual-purpose utility for high-resolution, multi-temporal environmental monitoring. Its balanced performance across metrics and adaptability to complex terrain conditions make it a promising tool for supporting forest conservation, early fire detection, and evidence-based policy interventions."
For more information on this research see: Deep Learning-Driven Multi-Temporal Detection: Leveraging DeeplabV3+/Efficientnet-B08 Semantic Segmentation for Deforestation and Forest Fire Detection. Remote Sensing, 2025,17(14):2333. (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/rs17142333.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Joe Soundararajan, Institute for Data Science and Informatics, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65201, United States. Additional authors for this research include Andrew Kalukin, Jordan Malof, Dong Xu.

urn:contentItem:6GCP-YT13-RSYC-Y0NW-00000-00Findings from Mizoram University Provides New Data on Ecology, Environment and Conservation (Combining Spatial and Elementary Analysis With Qualitative Approaches: a Novel Approach of Forest Fire Risk Detection, Mitigation, and Impact Analysis)2025-07-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisECOLOGY, ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATIONFindings from Mizoram University Provides New Data on Ecology, Environment and Conservation (Combining Spatial and Elementary Analysis With Qualitative Approaches: a Novel Approach of Forest Fire Risk Detection, Mitigation, and Impact Analysis)


2025 JUL 30 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Current study results on Ecology, Environment and Conservation have been published. According to news reporting from Aizawl, India, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires globally, influenced by numerous drivers, resulting in substantial ecological degradation, economic instability, loss of livelihood, and loss of life. Impact of forest fire on the spatial variations of soil nutrients and socio-ecology of communities in the ecologically sensitive region like Central Himalaya are rare."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Mizoram University, "For proper management, integration of knowledge regarding regional problems due to fire, local traditional practices to prevent fire, and present technologies at global level are necessary. This research takes a novel approach to develop comprehensive fire management system by integrating methods including Geographically Weighted Binary Logistic Regression to map fire probability, laboratory analysis of soil samples to assess the impact on soil nutrients, and qualitative surveys to understand the socio-ecological impacts. Parallelly, traditional knowledge on fire prevention is also gathered. By combining these elements, the study aims to create a well-rounded and effective fire management strategy. High fire-risk zones, including Rajaji National Park, Jim Corbett National Park, and Nainital, exhibit a fire probability exceeding 90%, primarily driven by elevation, aspect, temperature, and human proximity. The GWBLR model emerge as an excellent technique of fire risk assessment with 83.1% accuracy. Soil nutrient analysis reveals significant degradation in burned areas, with organic carbon, nitrogen, and potassium levels reduced by over 50%. Agricultural productivity loss, reduction in non-timber forest products, livelihood loss, and outmigration were the major challenges faced by the forest-dependent populous. The study emphasizes integrating geospatial models with traditional knowledge for comprehensive fire management."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Moreover, using pine needles for bio-briquettes to reduce fuel loads and enhance early warning systems can mitigate fire risks and the ecological consequences."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Combining Spatial and Elementary Analysis With Qualitative Approaches: a Novel Approach of Forest Fire Risk Detection, Mitigation, and Impact Analysis. Natural Hazards, 2025. Natural Hazards can be contacted at: Springer, One New York Plaza, Suite 4600, New York, Ny, United States. (Springer - www.springer.com; Natural Hazards - www.springerlink.com/content/0921-030x/)

urn:contentItem:6H0R-N6G3-RY2S-92WC-00000-00Nottingham Forest fires manager Ange Postecoglou minutes after 3-0 loss to Chelsea2025-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisSPORTS NEWSNottingham Forest fires manager Ange Postecoglou minutes after 3-0 loss to ChelseaSTEVE DOUGLASAP Sports Writer

Nottingham Forest fired manager Ange Postecoglou around 20 minutes after a 3-0 loss to Chelsea on Saturday and just 39 days after the Australian took over.

Postecoglou didn’t win any of his eight matches in charge after replacing Nuno Espirito Santo on Sept. 9 and owner Evangelos Marinakis made a ruthless call after Forest's fourth straight loss in all competitions.

“Nottingham Forest Football Club can confirm that after a series of disappointing results and performances, Ange Postecoglou has been relieved of his duties as head coach with immediate effect,” a statement read.

“The club will make no further comment at this time.”

It was Postecoglou's first job since being fired by Tottenham at the end of last season despite leading Spurs to the Europa League title to break their 17-year trophy drought.

Forest lost six and drew the other two of its eight games under Postecoglou. That included four losses from five in the league, scoring just one goal in the process, to leave Forest hovering just above the bottom three.

Nuno was fired despite leading Forest into Europe following a very public falling-out with Marinakis, reportedly stemming from a breakdown in relations with the club’s recently hired global head of football, Edu Gaspar.

Postecoglou seemed an odd choice as the replacement, given his preferred style of play — on the front foot and attacking — differed to Nuno's and the squad in place at the City Ground.

If the idea was for Postecoglou to bring a more expansive approach to Forest, it didn't materialize. In five league games under the Australian, the team scored one goal.

There were loud jeers at the fulltime whistle at the Chelsea game.

Who next?

There was no immediate word of a replacement but British media has already reported that Sean Dyche, the former Burnley and Everton manager, was in line to take over should Forest fire Postecoglou.

Dyche was sacked by Everton in January. He was a youth-team player at Forest before a career spent at lower-league clubs.

His direct and pragmatic playing style is more similar to Nuno's than Postecoglou's.

urn:contentItem:6GM7-C233-RT10-S2H2-00000-00Letter: Fires have arrived2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisLetter: Fires have arrived

1. The following is not a rant; its purpose is not to complain or criticize.

2. I have no firefighting experience either ‘on the ground' or as an administrator.

The Manson Creek forest fire (about 12 km from downtown Nanaimo and Nanaimo Airport) and the Panorama Ridge house fires (about 3 km from Chemainus and Saltair) constitute a wake-up call for all levels of government and the population at large. The forest fire, which started on Aug. 24, is considered ‘under control' as of today, Thursday, Aug. 28. The Panorama Ridge fire happened on Aug. 25; it destroyed one house and did quite a bit of damage to another residence.

The Manson Creek fire is not the first Vancouver Island conflagration to get our attention this summer, but its proximity to the Island Highway and to the City of Nanaimo (pop. 100,000) adds extra motivation to examine how prepared we are to handle the new normal of yearly, multiple major fires.

The complete or partial burning of towns (as happened to Lytton, Fort McMurray, and Jasper) could easily happen here because: 1. we live in a heavily forested landscape and 2. the dry/drought season is increasing in intensity and duration. The current, elevated temperatures are an anomaly for the end of August.

The Panorama Ridge house fire could have ignited the surrounding trees and the Manson Creek forest fire could have extended its reach to highly populated areas and to the Island Highway. In similar situations across Canada, evacuation orders went out to towns which were significantly further away from forest fires than the Manson Creek fire was from Port Alberni, Nanaimo, and Chemainus. Smoke can shut down a highway for days, and as we live on an island, only limited escape routes are available.

The above-cited incidents tell us that it is time to assess our ability to handle all kinds of fires and to determine how to correct any deficits in our ability to ward off the catastrophes that are occurring more and more frequently in Canada, North America, and around the globe. As individual citizens, it's increasingly urgent that we properly prepare ourselves for prolonged exposure to smoke, disrupted travel, broken supply chains, and evacuation.

Jonathan Churcher

Ladysmith

urn:contentItem:6H4V-2WN3-RX69-53PF-00000-00At a Full Queer show, drag is a contact sport | Local Events | dailycal.org2025-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1At a Full Queer show, drag is a contact sport | Local Events | dailycal.org

This week marks roughly a year since President Donald Trump was reelected into office, which turned sparks of bigotry into a full-on forest fire targeting our country's most vulnerable. The past few months have seen many marginalized groups reduced to feelings of hopelessness and isolation.

However, if you had the pleasure of attending Full Queer: Wrestling for Rights' end-of-year showdown, "THERE IS STILL TIME," like I did, you would have been struck by an entirely different tone. From the second the first bell rang to the final tap out, Standard Deviant Brewing at San Francisco's Pier 70 was filled with unbridled queer joy - showcased through the unconventional form of a wrestling show.

The first step onto the back patio of Standard Deviant immediately immersed patrons into a buzzing environment of pride. Pride flags decorated tables as vendors sold pins, stickers, and patches advocating against borders and police officers in favor of liberation, wrestling arenas and punk rock. Every shade of what has been deemed "freakish" by the mainstream world was well represented on this pier. 

It's clear that representation was a priority for the organizers, as it shined through not only in their decor but also in their lineup of wrestlers. The first match of the afternoon, Brian Bomb vs. Andrew Cass, was informally dubbed "bear vs. twink." Whatever your preference, there was a type of gay to root for, though as the delightfully animated commentators pointed out, "One can only hear the word twink so many times and not root for him."

After Cass was crowned the king and tag teams took to the mat, one thing became very clear: Roughly half of the audience, myself included, had zero clue about the rules of wrestling. But honestly, it didn't really matter - Full Queer was, above all else, a platform for queer canon: showmanship, creativity and theatricality. Really, "THERE IS STILL TIME" was designed for anyone who has ever stopped to think about the pure homoeroticism that emanates throughout wrestling, typically a sport where men fight to dominate one another. 

Ultimately, the fighters didn't care how much you knew about the rules either - they were ready to deliver a show for an audience that spanned various spectrums, whether it be wrestling knowledge, queerness or age. Sure, sometimes it was obvious that a punch did not actually land, but it was hard to be put off by the sloppier moments when the 5-year-old next to you was cheering on his favorite fighter.

Alternatively, Full Queer asks the unheard question: Is there a difference between wrestling and drag culture? Wrestling matches see players prance onto the stage as energizing music surrounds them, much like how a drag show sees a queen dramatically take to the stage as her first song of the night plays. Wrestlers create characteristic and stylistic motifs for their in-ring selves just like how queens come up with creative names and costumes for their on-stage personas. And really, how different is a WWE match from the "Lip Sync for Your Life" segment on RuPaul's Drag Race? 

"THERE IS STILL TIME" was a show with a heart beating with love - not only for their fans, but also for the beautiful city in which they were performing. Not only was the view of the Bay from Pier 70 undeniably breathtaking, but various moments throughout the afternoon showered San Francisco as a whole with warming love. Grateful "thank yous" were shouted at the San Francisco Fire Department while they gleefully watched the first match, mentions of the previous Full Queer event at the Folsom Street Fair were met with applause and the commentators were eager to shout out bars in the Castro District. San Francisco has long been a pillar for queer resistance and liberation, and Full Queer happily acknowledged that during their smackdowns.

Whether you attend with a love for wrestling's intense fights or for a campy queer environment, Full Queer shows provide a silver lining. After all, as commentator and Full Queer co-founder Rosie Fingers said, "We persevere, and we persevere together."

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y623-RS92-20YM-00000-00Fire in Tolata is still active and winds make it difficult to control it2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisFire in Tolata is still active and winds make it difficult to control it


The forest fire that affects since Monday afternoon the Tolata mountain range, in the high valley of Cochabamba, continues active this Tuesday, due to the strong winds that prevented its suffocation, informed the Risk Management Unit (UGR) of the Governor's Office.


"Yesterday (Monday) we worked until the evening hours, however, the wind gusts increased and did not allow the personnel to continue operating. For security reasons we have had all personnel withdrawn", explained to Unitel the head of the UGR, Ramiro López.
Tolata
The authority said that in the morning new first response teams of the Search and Rescue Service (SAR-FAB) and volunteer brigades were deployed, in coordination with the municipality and other institutions, to resume fire control work.
The fire originated in Sacaba and, favored by the wind, spread to Tolata, affecting large wooded areas. Although in Sacaba the fire has already been controlled, in Tolata it has not yet been put out.
"It has been growing, yesterday it was quite windy and these are favorable conditions for the development of the fire. Now it is being fought from this municipality (Tolata)," said Lopez.
Fires
There is still no official estimate of the number of hectares damaged. The authorities informed that this figure will be determined once the fire is under control.
With this one, Cochabamba adds another forest fire in the last weeks. At the end of August, in Tunari Park, more than 350 hectares of forest were consumed by flames. For this reason, the decision was made to restrict access until December, when the fire season ends.
At the moment, the causes of the fire in Tolata are unknown. However, the authorities do not rule out the possibility that it is an arson attack, as occurred in Tunari Park and other regions of the country.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5DF3-S4Y1-952F-00000-00The Civil Guard in Cáceres clarifies the authorship of 17 forest fires2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisThe Civil Guard in Cáceres clarifies the authorship of 17 forest fires


Agents of the Guardia Civil, belonging to the Nature Protection Service (SEPRONA) of the Command of Cáceres, have carried out several criminal investigations in connection with forest fires which have occurred in the province during the last few months. These actions have allowed to clarify seventeen fires, with the arrest of four persons for crimes committed intentionally and the criminal investigation of six others for fires caused by serious negligence.


August 31st. Valverde del Fresno
Agents of the Post of Valverde del Fresno (Cáceres), arrested on August 31 a woman as the alleged perpetrator of two forest fires committed, allegedly intentionally, in the municipality of this town during the month of August. These are minor forest fires, which have the common characteristic of having their point of origin in areas close to communication routes.
August 30. Aldeanueva del Camino
SEPRONA agents arrested a man as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of arson, which took place on August 29, in the vicinity of the town of Aldeanueva del Camino (Cáceres), with two outbreaks. After the rapid intervention of the extinguishing services, only about 300 and 10 square meters were affected respectively.
August 25. Millanes and Saucedilla
Fires were recorded in this area, in the municipalities of Millanes and Saucedilla (Cáceres), within a repeated series of fires during 2024 and 2025 with identical "modus operandi": direct application of fire on roadsides on dry vegetation. In total, there were five fires in 2025 (15 and 20 July and 10 August) and three in 2024 (17 and 20 July and 4 August). As a result of the investigation, with the support of the Investigation Area of the Main Post of Navalmoral de la Mata (Cáceres), a woman was arrested as the alleged perpetrator of several intentional forest fires.
August 20. Arroyomolinos de la Vera
On July 17, a fire started in a plot of fruit trees, where there was an accumulation of debris and sawdust that favored the spread of the fire. The owner of the property was investigated by SEPRONA as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of forest fire due to serious negligence.
August 19. Valdecañas de Tajo
A fire on June 17 originated in the enclosure of a natural swimming pool. The investigation determined that the branches of an ornamental tree had hit a power line, releasing incandescent material which caused the fire. A man was investigated by SEPRONA as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of forest fire due to gross negligence, due to negligence in the maintenance of the power line.
6th August. Ceclavín
On this occasion, a fire which took place on June 20 burned around 300 hectares of pastures. The fire started next to a detonating cannon used as a scarecrow. Each detonation caused small flames that started the fire. As a result, the owner of the device was investigated as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of forest fire due to gross negligence.
August 6. Valdefuentes
A fire on July 27 affected a hectare of pasture and fig trees. The investigation led to the identification of the driver of a vehicle that had circulated in the starting area, who admitted his involvement in the fire. He was arrested as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of arson.
July 24. Villanueva de la Vera
A fire on June 29th forced the activation of level 1 of the INFOEX Plan, evacuating 10 houses and 17 people. More than 40 hectares of forest and agricultural area were burned. The investigation determined that the origin was a poorly maintained power line. The person in charge of the company owning the line was investigated as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of forest fire due to gross negligence.
July 15, . Eljas
A fire on July 14 burned 1 hectare of pasture and fig trees. The technical report of causes accredited the existence of intentional fire, applying flame directly on dead fine fuel, noting that the place where it started had been accessed with a tractor. Agents of the Post of Valverde del Fresno (Cáceres) investigated the owner of this vehicle, and the SEPRONA agents managed to find out that the fire had been caused intentionally, by direct application of flame on the dead fine fuel. Finally, on July 15, the man was investigated as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of arson.
July 9. Aldea del Obispo
A fire on June 15 affected around 15 hectares of grasses and leguminous plants. SEPRONA located the starting point and determined that the fire was caused by the negligence of a neighbor when burning domestic waste. The wind displaced the embers towards dry combustible material, causing the fire. Once the causes were determined, the person responsible was investigated as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of forest fire committed by gross negligence.
They are in addition to other recent SEPRONA actions. In May, they managed to arrest an individual allegedly involved in seven intentional forest fires in the area of Casas del Castañar and Cabrero (Cáceres). The judicial authority ordered him to be remanded in custody, where he remains three months after his arrest. Likewise, in July, the "Oldburn operation" culminated in the arrest of a woman as the alleged perpetrator of several arson attacks in Villamesías (Cáceres).

urn:contentItem:6H34-BFT3-RSXV-P4X4-00000-00Findings from Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications Provide New Insights into Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (Exploring the Robustness: Hierarchical Federated Learning Framework for Object Detection of Uav Cluster)2025-10-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisAVIATION - UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLEFindings from Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications Provide New Insights into Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (Exploring the Robustness: Hierarchical Federated Learning Framework for Object Detection of Uav Cluster)


2025 OCT 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Defense & Aerospace Daily -- Researchers detail new data in Aviation - Unmanned Aerial Vehicle. According to news reporting originating from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The deployment of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) cluster is an available solution for object detection missions. In the harsh environment, UAV cluster could suffer from some significant threats (e.g., forest fire hazards, electromagnetic interference, and ground-to-air attacks), which could lead to the destruction of UAVs and loss of data."


Funders for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC), Postgraduate Research & Practice Innovation Program of Jiangsu Province.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, "To this end, we propose a Hierarchical Federated Learning Framework for Object Detection (HFL-OD) to enhance the robustness of UAV cluster conducting object detection missions. In HFL-OD, UAVs are grouped through a Three-Dimensional (3D) graph coloring method, and an intragroup backup mechanism is provided to prevent the data loss caused by the destruction of UAVs. Besides, a dynamic server selection mechanism deals with the potential destruction of servers (cluster server and group servers) by adaptively reassigning the server roles. To further improve the robustness and mission efficiency of UAV cluster, a two-tier federated learning framework is introduced to make a proper trade-off between object detection accuracy and communication/computational overhead. This framework is built on the concept of hierarchical federated learning by implementing both intragroup parameter aggregation and global parameter aggregation."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Extensive simulations and comparisons demonstrate the superior performance of our proposed HFL-OD, i.e., the robustness of UAV cluster conducting object detection missions can be significantly improved, and the communication/computational overhead is effectively reduced."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Exploring the Robustness: Hierarchical Federated Learning Framework for Object Detection of Uav Cluster. Ieee Transactions On Mobile Computing, 2025;24(10):9489-9505. Ieee Transactions On Mobile Computing can be contacted at: Ieee Computer Soc, 10662 Los Vaqueros Circle, PO Box 3014, Los Alamitos, CA 90720-1314, USA. (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers - www.ieee.org/; Ieee Transactions On Mobile Computing - ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/RecentIssue.jsp?punumber=7755)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Linfeng Liu, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, School of Computer Science and Technology, Nanjing 210023, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Xingyu Li, Wenzhe Zhang and Jia Xu.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1109/TMC.2025.3562812. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6H17-2C23-RWDJ-H0NX-00000-00Wildfires spread across Lower Peninsula as drought continues - The Lode2025-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Wildfires spread across Lower Peninsula as drought continues - The LodeHannah Marlor

Fire crews spent the last week battling the Benzie Road Fire near Houghton Lake in Roscommon State Forest, Michigan. The fire grew to 101 acres before it was contained, according to the Michigan Department of Natural Resources. 

Mid-Michigan has been experiencing moderate to severe droughts due to a lack of rainfall since early September. The ongoing dry spell in the northern Lower Peninsula played a major role in the fire's size and intensity. As droughts become more frequent and severe, fires like these will become more common. Additionally, droughts contribute to "weaker, poorly formed trees that are susceptible to disease," which, when left unmanaged, lead to "lots of ladder fuel, and potential for downward spiral," according to Jim Schmierer, who is the professor of Michigan Tech's wildland fire course. Schmierer explained that when fuel accumulates, it doesn't take much to start a forest fire. "It could be a cigarette, an ember from a campfire, or a small fire that got away," he said. 

Forest fires can become intense and out of control under drought conditions, but low to moderate-intensity fires are a natural disturbance that play an essential role in forest ecology. "Fire is never 'bad', but it can burn at intensities that might not be normal based on forest cover type and ecosystem," said Gavin Kelso, second-year forestry student and President of the Wildland Fire Club. "'Bad' would make a forest irreparable, but that never happens. Plants come back in." Kelso explained that reintroducing fire into an ecosystem can restore it to its natural state, though this process is challenging when too much fuel has accumulated, as discussed earlier. However, forest management practices such as removing smaller trees and undergrowth can solve this by reducing the risk of an out-of-control fire. 

Students interested in wildland fire can take Schmierer's course or get hands-on training through the Wildland Fire Club. Visit "Wildland Fire Club" on Involvement Link or message them on Instagram at @mtu_wildlandfireclub.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DFT3-RRR5-S1G0-00000-00The CSI of fire: how a fire is investigated as an environmental crime2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisThe CSI of fire: how a fire is investigated as an environmental crime


Traveling to kilometer zero of a forest fire is an arduous path that is traveled in reverse. Fire, which devastates almost everything, also leaves its mark. It is not a perfect crime. It leaves characteristic marks in the earth, the trunks, the stones... Significant marks that are the ones that the Seprona unit of the Guardia Civil and the agents of the Forest Fire Investigation Unit (UIFO) of the Rural Environment are looking for. They are the fire detectives.


The investigation begins when the fire is out and the area is secured. The perimeter must be documented to search for the origin and try to understand its development, crossing the data with meteorological variables: wind, temperature, humidity....
"It's like investigating the scene of a crime," explains to El Confidencial Daniel Barturen, captain of the Seprona in Pontevedra, who has been chasing those first flames and their authors for years. Before disembarking in Galicia, he integrated the UCOMA, the Central Operational Environmental Unit of the Civil Guard, and was tanned in the great fires of Granada (2022), Asturias or Tenerife (2023).
"You have to follow the physical evidence until you find the starting area".
He tells that it is a meticulous technical process that is based "on the physical evidence", until a hypothesis is put together to corroborate with testimonies and other circumstantial evidence. "The fire, as it advances, leaves some marks. We have to take into account the slope and the direction of the wind. We follow these traces on inert objects until we find the starting area. They mark them with cones and flags - metric witnesses - and take samples and photographs as in the investigation of any other crime.
Then, Barturen explains, they look for "activity indicators". From a cigarette butt thrown into the woods to a power line cable, garbage or an incendiary device. They also watch any cameras in the area for clues. And they can.
Often, says Captain Barturen, finding the cause is much less complicated than putting the perpetrator in the dock. It's the only thing that doesn't leave a trace," but there are other ways of catching them, he warns. "There is some confusion between the arsonist, who is a diagnosed mental disorder, and the arsonist, who is a person who is looking for personal or economic gain. He may do it out of revenge, out of malice, to see if he gets hired or because he makes money."
"The only thing that doesn't leave a mark is a lighter," laments a Seprona captain.
Barturen landed at his new destination in April. In Pontevedra alone, the system registered 558 fire warnings in 2025. One of the difficulties encountered in rural nuclei and scattered populations is that they have internalized fire as a "tool" (burning, backfires...) that they do not always know how to control, especially after a rainy spring that gave way to an extraordinarily hot summer, as has happened this year, where more than 300,000 hectares have already been burned throughout Spain. "The problem is that the type of vegetation and fuel conditions have changed in recent years. There are more eucalyptus and pine trees and fewer oak and chestnut trees. Weeds, high temperatures and strong winds formed a Molotov cocktail," he concludes about Galicia.
The Galician fire CSI
Four years ago the Xunta decided to create its own Forest Fire Investigation Unit (UIFO), which works closely with the Police and Civil Guard. It is made up of environmental agents, attached to the General Directorate for the Defense of the Rural Environment. They use drones, video surveillance cameras in areas of high incendiary activity and make use of their knowledge of the terrain over the 19 forest districts in which Galicia is divided to narrow the circle on causes and perpetrators. "Their work is fundamental," praises a high command of the Armed Institute. In 2024, 12 people were brought to court as alleged arsonists.
. The penalties appear in the Penal Code from article 352 onwards and would carry up to 20 years in prison depending on the risk to people, the damage caused or if it is a protected area.
Prison for a repeat offender
The judge of Verín ordered last Wednesday the provisional imprisonment without bail for the 47-year-old man arrested as the alleged perpetrator of a forest fire in Vilardevós (Ourense). He spent the night in jail and refused to testify. He had a previous record for having caused damage with a fire, according to the Superior Court of Justice of Galicia (TSXG), although it was not a forest fire.
The Ourense municipality of Vilardevós concentrated these days up to three simultaneous fires in Vilar de Cervos (900 hectares), Moialde (500), Fumaces and A Trepa (100), which Medio Rural considers stabilized. The man is attributed the authorship of the second one "which burned an area of 578.7 hectares". The same individual had already spent some time in prison for setting fires and his neighbors of Terroso repudiated him. Due to his repeated offenses and "his personal circumstances", the judge sent him to the Pereiro de Aguiar prison.
Since June 1, 37 people have been arrested and 113 investigated for their possible relationship with some of the fires burning in Spain. In Galicia, since July, 11 have been arrested and 22 others are being investigated, according to the Government Delegation. Among the people arrested there are diverse profiles and disparate situations: an 81-year-old woman in Celanova and two younger ones in Muxía and Cee. Another subject was caught red-handed setting fire to the mountains surrounding Ourense and this week the case of a young boy, a minor, who is attributed with several arson attacks in the surroundings of Santiago, attracted attention. He was carrying several lighters with which he tried to unleash chaos. He has been placed in a center for minors.
Traveling to kilometer zero of a forest fire is an arduous path that is traveled in reverse. Fire, which devastates almost everything, also leaves its mark. It is not a perfect crime. It leaves characteristic marks on the earth, the trunks, the stones... Significant marks that are the ones that the Seprona unit of the Guardia Civil and the agents of the Forest Fire Investigation Unit (UIFO) of the Rural Environment are looking for. They are the fire detectives.

urn:contentItem:6GS9-PSD3-RS7X-7393-00000-00The Provincial Council highlights the good preparation of the province of Barcelona in the face of fires2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisThe Provincial Council highlights the good preparation of the province of Barcelona in the face of fires


The Barcelona Provincial Council today took stock of this summer's fire prevention season and stressed that the province of Barcelona is one of the best prepared territories in Spain to deal with forest fires.
The Provincial Council, through the Technical Office of Forest Fire Prevention, allocates 13.1 million euros each year to prevention, which includes planning and infrastructure, strategic forest management, support for Forest Defense Associations (ADF) and the Information and Surveillance Plan against Forest Fires (PVI).


This summer there have been 108 forest fires in the province of Barcelona, which have burned a total of 211.88 hectares.
This year's PVI has informed 56,544 people, detected 2,406 spills and 1,807 power lines in poor condition.
A total of 280 municipalities in the demarcation have a Fire Prevention Plan (PP)I in force drafted by the Provincial Council, which represents all the municipalities obliged or recommended by Infocat.
The PVI, which is deployed every year by the Natural Areas and Green Infrastructure Area of the Barcelona Provincial Council through the Technical Office of Forest Fire Prevention, has closed this summer's campaign with 108 forest, agricultural or peri-urban fires recorded. The device has been carried out between June 18 and August 31 in 275 municipalities in the province and has affected a total of 211.88 hectares. Last year there were more fires (135), but with a smaller area (26.87 hectares).
Anoia and Bages, the most affected counties
Of the fires this year, 44.6% were in wooded forest mass, 37.5% in agricultural land and 18% in scrubland. The Anoia region was the most affected (132.70 ha), followed by Bages (33.36 ha), Vallès Occidental (22.96 ha) and Baix Llobregat (16.83 ha).
Jordi Fàbrega, deputy delegate of Fire Prevention and Forest Management of the Provincial Council, stressed that "Barcelona is one of the territories of the state better prepared for forest fires" and explained that, "despite the adverse conditions of this summer, in the province we have come out quite well".
"We believe that the support that, for many years, the Diputació de Barcelona has been providing in the municipal world in terms of fire prevention has been fundamental," added Fàbrega. In this sense, he said that "investing is prevention" and pointed out the importance of doing this task throughout the year, "because fires are extinguished in winter".
The deputy also recalled that "managing forest land is key to fire prevention and that it is necessary to move towards a circular economy around our forests".
The axes of the prevention strategy deployed by the Diputació de Barcelona include technical assistance and economic resources to municipalities for the construction and improvement of territorial infrastructures for the prevention of forest fires -such as the maintenance and consolidation of water points-, information and surveillance against forest fires, prevention of forest fires in urbanizations and population centers, forest restoration and improvement tasks and the acquisition of vehicles for the ADF.
This year's PVI has reinforced the action on the territory with a more focused approach, the identification of impact zones, more support to the ADF, 24-hour technological surveillance and an organization more adapted to local realities. This has made it possible to act more efficiently, as can be seen from the data obtained during the 75 days of the campaign.
PVI personnel have directly informed 56,544 people that they were in housing estates, farmhouses, roads, tracks, forests, monuments, viewpoints, urban areas, industrial estates and recreational areas. This means that each civic agent has informed 10 people every day, which is 132% more efficient than in the previous campaign, when the average number of people informed per agent was 4.
The county where the new PVI model has been most efficient with respect to informers has been Bages, where it has gone from 5 people informed per day per civic agent in 2024 to 30 this year.
With respect to the detection of spills, during the 2025 campaign each civic agent detected 20 spills, while in 2022 there were 4. This makes a total of 2,406 spills detected in this campaign, a figure significantly higher than last year, when 1,732 were counted.
The region where the new model has been more efficient with respect to detection has been the Maresme, where the number of spills detected has increased from 5 spills for each informant to 35.
Removal of spills and detection of power lines in poor condition
With regard to the direct removal of small spills, this summer each civic agent has removed 13, while in 2022 there were 3. The county with the highest efficiency in the removal has been Vallès Oriental, where the number of spills removed by each informer during the previous campaign has increased from 2 to 21.
All the spills have been notified to the corresponding municipalities and 921 have been removed at the time by the Civic Agents of the device. In this regard, the Diputació de Barcelona, through its 2024 services catalog, granted financial aid to municipalities for the removal of spills with risk of forest fire in a total of 81 municipalities in the province of Barcelona. The total amount was 170,191 euros for the removal of 356 spills.
With regard to the detection of incidents in power lines in poor condition and which do not comply with fire prevention regulations, 1,807 incidents were detected, more than twice as many as in the previous campaign, when 876 were located.
All of them have been notified to the electricity company, and 6.42% have been resolved. The regions where the most incidents of this type have been resolved were Vallès Occidental, Maresme and Anoia.
The rest of the actions this year have been incidents in road infrastructures (220), revision of water points (2,409) and dissuasion actions (96) for barbecues that do not comply with the regulations, use of tools that generate sparks or for burning and other dangerous activities.
With an investment of 2.4 million euros, the Information and Surveillance Plan against Forest Fires 2025 was deployed last June 18 in 275 municipalities in the province of Barcelona and was extended until August 31. The device, which has covered more than 615,000 agroforestry hectares, has been integrated by 96 professionals and has deployed 37 mobile information and awareness units. In addition, there were 5 watchtowers with fixed surveillance.
The device collaborates jointly with 275 town councils, 126 forest defense groups (ADF), 9 federations of ADF, the Secretariat of Federations and ADF of Catalonia and other administrations to prevent forest fires and limit their effects.
280 municipalities with a Fire Prevention Plan in place
The serious fires in Spain in the summer of 2025 have led the Environmental Prosecutor's Office to increase its efforts to identify those municipalities that do not have a municipal forest fire prevention plan (PPI) drafted and approved.
In Catalonia it is Law 6/88 which obliges all local entities located in high fire risk areas to have a PPI which must be approved by the competent Department. Decree 64/95 on forest fire prevention measures determines in its annex which municipalities are in high fire risk areas.
In the province of Barcelona, a total of 212 municipalities in the fire risk zone have a current IPP drafted by the Provincial Council and have funding from the corporation for the execution of the planned actions. These municipalities represent the totality of the municipalities of the demarcation that are listed as being at risk of fire in Decree 64/95.
Additionally, the Diputació de Barcelona offers the drafting of the PPI, and the financing for the execution of works to 68 municipalities with more than 100 hectares of vulnerable forest area and that need to have an emergency plan (PALMO) according to INFOCAT.
These 68 municipalities, added to the 212 at high risk of fire, currently add up to a total of 280 municipalities with a PPI in force in the demarcation.

urn:contentItem:6GPT-XJ63-SH9C-520P-00000-00Forest fire alerts increase in the center of the country: in Cordoba eight outbreaks controlled in one day2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:15ZLexisNexisForest fire alerts increase in the center of the country: in Cordoba eight outbreaks controlled in one day


In the last few days, the weather started to improve in most of the country. The cold is slowly being left in the past and the arrival of spring is expected. However, the stability of the days does not always mean good news: wind and heat are a risk of forest fires in much of the center of the country.


That is why in this region, where this Wednesday there were alerts due to the winds, they are already preparing to prevent outbreaks that may end up impacting the vegetation in the area. Even greater is the fear that it may happen in places close to houses.
Even in Córdoba, these situations have already begun to be experienced, where up to eight igneous outbreaks have developed in areas such as La Calera, Jesús María, Achiras, Alta Gracia, Despeñaderos, Tulumba, as well as in the vicinity of El Arañado and Deán Funes.
The Government of the province informed that the different fire outbreaks registered during the day on Wednesday have been contained, according to the Secretariat of Risk Management.
The operation deployed covered several points of the affected territory. The brigades, integrated by volunteer firefighters and personnel from the Fire Management Direction of the Ministry of Security, continue working on the field to ensure the control of the perimeters and prevent the flames from becoming active again, considering the persistence of strong winds in the region.
The strategy implemented included the participation of the Dirección Provincial de Aeronáutica (Provincial Aeronautics Directorate), which provided for the use of three hydrant aircrafts. The aerial tasks were vital to contain the active fronts in Achiras, Alta Gracia and Despeñaderos.
As an additional preventive measure, the authorities established that a hydrant aircraft will remain on alert in Alta Gracia, while another one will be available at the base of the Provincial Aeronautics Directorate, an organization that operates with an active guard all day long to guarantee a quick response to any emergency.
The fire alert remains extremely high in the province. The state of environmental alert decreed in Córdoba has been in force since June 2 and will last at least until December 31 of the current year. This determination derives from the exponential increase in the risk of fire after the arrival of the first frosts, a phenomenon that dries out vegetation and turns it into material susceptible to combustion. Valley and mountain areas are particularly vulnerable under these climatic conditions.
In this context, spokesman Roberto Schreiner emphasized: "We ask the population to please remember that it is forbidden to light fires in the whole territory of the province of Córdoba".
In addition, the National Meteorological Service reported a yellow alert due to intense winds affecting the capital city, as well as the central and southern regions of Córdoba.
The agency said that the phenomenon will reach greater intensity this Wednesday, with gusts of more than 60km/h expected in the morning. During the afternoon, the wind rotated to the south and intensified even more in the central region. In Cordoba, gusts exceeded 75 km/h, bringing with them clouds of dust.
The report also indicates a significant increase in temperature, as the maximum reached 28 degrees in the capital city of Córdoba, according to the SMN, driven by winds from the north and southwest.
For its part, the Provincial Police issued an additional warning about the possibility of "reduced visibility due to dust in suspension and extreme risk of fire", and urged the population to circulate with caution and avoid any action that may cause fire outbreaks.

Charlotte Oliver

July 24th, 2025 ( VTDigger - Delivered by Newstex )

Smoke from a fire in Fair Haven spotted overhead on Tuesday evening. Courtesy photo by Dan Brown

Pilot Dan Brown was flying over Fair Haven on Tuesday night when he spotted smokestacks bulloughing up from the woods around sunset. He alerted firefighters, and since then, they've been battling a blaze spread across 11 acres of forested private property.

The fire first started when the property owner was burning brush to clear shooting lanes for hunting, said James Heller, Fair Haven's Fire Chief. The property owner didn't realize that he failed to put out the fire, he said.

With pretty dry conditions, the fire grew in a remote part of the woods where people didn't take notice.

That is, until Brown was flying a private plane overhead before sunset. Struck by the quantity of smoke coming from the woods, he alerted the Fire Department in Castleton and sent over pictures of what he saw.

Two days later, on Thursday afternoon, 35 state firefighters were on site, working alongside crews from Castleton, Rutland City, Poultney and Whitehall with help from the U.S. Forest Service, Heller said.

Map via Vermont Agency of Natural Resources

The groups are trying to maintain a perimeter to contain the blaze. The fire is largely burning underground and is very far from any structures, Heller said.

'They're attempting to establish a water supply and get a hose line up to their fire line,' Heller said.

Without road access to the area, crews have only been able to get to the fire on 4-wheelers. From above, state hazmat teams used drones and infrared mapping to pinpoint fire hot spots, and follow its movement.

Crews of fire fighters have been cycling in and out to bring in 'fresh troops,' Heller said. They thought they had the fire contained within 10 acres until a breeze on Wednesday morning spread flames further. Now, it's looking like winds will push the fire to the north or northeast, Heller said.

The blaze is what's called a duff fire, which eats through plant material like leaves and bark that are compacted under the forest floor.

'The only thing that's gonna ultimately quench it is gonna be a good rain,' Heller said.

It's important for people to keep an eye on daily fire danger reports from the state because 'while it may look green, it can be sneakily dry in the understory,' said Megan Davin, a spokesperson for the state's Wildland Fire Team, which is fighting the fire.

Fair Haven has been considered high risk for fires throughout most of the summer, Davin said. A strip of the state, including Fair Haven, keeps getting missed by rain while other parts of the state get hit, leading to unusually dry conditions.

On Tuesday evening, when they heard from Brown, the pilot, firefighters in Castleton reached out to those in Fair Haven, who fought the fire for more than four hours on Tuesday night with crews from two other towns.

When the fire spread beyond containment on Wednesday, crews from five different municipalities worked on-site for nine hours. And a number of statewide emergency response groups have chipped in resources, along with the U.S. Forest Service.

With hot temperatures on Thursday, those fighting the fire are trying to stay cool, Heller said. He's thankful for all of the resources they've gotten from around and beyond the state, he said.

Tomorrow, they hope for rain.

'Anything we get is gonna be a blessing,' Heller said.
