urn:contentItem:6H2P-CYB3-S1DV-X3PY-00000-00Researchers' from Southwest Forestry University Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Remote Sensing (Enhancing Wildfire Monitoring with SDGSAT-1: A Performance Analysis)2025-10-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGResearchers' from Southwest Forestry University Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Remote Sensing (Enhancing Wildfire Monitoring with SDGSAT-1: A Performance Analysis)


2025 OCT 27 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Data detailed on remote sensing have been presented. According to news reporting from Kunming, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Advancements in remote sensing technology have enabled the acquisition of high spatial and radiometric resolution imagery, offering abundant and reliable data sources for forest fire monitoring."


Funders for this research include Yunnan Provincial Science And Technology Plan Project; National Natural Foundation Committee; National Forestry Science And Technology Promotion Project of China; Yunnan Provincial Department of Education; Key Research And Development Project of Guangxi; Yunnan Xingdian Talent Industry Innovation Project; Yunnan Provincial Department of Education Postgraduate Tutor Team Project; Yunnan Provincial International Science And Technology Envoy Certification.
Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Southwest Forestry University: "In order to explore the ability of Sustainable Development Science Satellite 1 (SDGSAT-1) in wildfire monitoring, a systematic and comprehensive study was proposed on smoke detection during the wildfire early warning phase, fire point identification during the fire occurrence, and burned area delineation after the wildfire. The smoke detection effect of SDGSAT-1 was analyzed by machine learning and the discriminating potential of SDGSAT-1 burned area was discussed by Mid-Infrared Burn Index (MIRBI) and Normalized Burn Ratio 2 (NBR2). In addition, compared with Sentinel-2, the fixed-threshold method and the two-channel fixed-threshold plus contextual approach are further used to demonstrate the performance of SDGSAT-1 in fire point identification. The results show that the average accuracy of SDGSAT-1 fire burned area recognition is 90.21%, and a clear fire boundary can be obtained. The average smoke detection precision is 81.72%, while the fire point accuracy is 97.40%, and the minimum identified fire area is 0.0009 km2, which implies SDGSAT-1 offers significant advantages in the early detection and identification of small-scale fires, which is significant in fire emergency and disposal. The performance of fire point detection is superior to that of Sentinel-2 and Landsat 8."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "SDGSAT-1 demonstrates great potential in monitoring the entire process of wildfire occurrence, development, and evolution. With its higher-resolution satellite imagery, it has become an important data source for monitoring in the field of remote sensing."
For more information on this research see: Enhancing Wildfire Monitoring with SDGSAT-1: A Performance Analysis. Remote Sensing, 2025,17(19):3339. (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/rs17193339.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Xinkun Zhu, School of Forestry, Southwest Forestry University, Kunming 650224, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Guojiang Zhang, Bo Xiang, Jiangxia Ye, Lei Kong, Wenlong Yang, Mingshan Wu, Song Yang, Wenquan Wang, Weili Kou, Qiuhua Wang, Zhichao Huang.
Keywords for this news article include: Southwest Forestry University, Kunming, People's Republic of China, Asia, Remote Sensing, Technology.

urn:contentItem:6GMX-5SR3-RWBN-637V-00000-00Forest fires in Spain: regional responsibilities and the risk of politicking2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisForest fires in Spain: regional responsibilities and the risk of politicking

Forest fire in Spain (Extremadura, Cabezuela del Valle). Public domain image with required attribution: Copernicus Sentinel-2, EU.
Responsibility lies with the autonomous communities
In Spain, forest fire prevention and extinction is mainly the responsibility of the autonomous communities, as established by the Constitution (art. 148.1), the Forestry Law and the autonomous statutes.


The central government, through MITECO, can deploy support means, but not assume direct management except in cases of national emergency (Newtral; MITECO; La Razón).
Therefore, in the face of the recent devastating wave of fires, the first responsibility corresponds to the autonomous governments.
Was the aid provided by the central government adequate?
The assessment is complex and varies from case to case:
Late or insufficient claims.

However, communities such as Extremadura, Galicia or Castilla y León acknowledged that they asked for more means than the State could offer immediately.


Criticism of the lack of prior planning

Furthermore, El País stressed that although preventive plans had already been legislated in 2022, the central government failed to provide a homogeneous framework applicable throughout the territory, which revealed shortcomings in coordinated planning.

It is not the same thing to say that a national framework is lacking -which may be desirable- as to affirm, as El País suggests, that the central government left the communities without support. The reality is that state and European resources were activated, although their immediate availability did not always meet the demands of the autonomous communities.


Inter-autonomic solidarity

Political crisis and demand for responsibilities

Final reflection: the danger of trivializing politics
The forest fire tragedy should have been a moment of unity and serious management, but it became a source of political diatribe.
Central government and opposition, instead of cooperating, accused each other of negligence, using a national emergency as partisan ammunition.
This behavior is deeply irresponsible because it erodes confidence in democratic institutions. And let us not forget: Spain achieved democracy just over 40 years ago, the fruit of agreements and sacrifices, not easy concessions.
Political trivialization opens the door to groups with influence and abundant resources that do wish to weaken Spanish democracy. They are not few, and some of them have powerful means to manipulate public opinion.
The example of Venezuela is instructive: it was a solid democracy, recognized as an example in Latin America, until the trivialization of political debate and the rise of populism eroded it. Today the country suffers from an authoritarian regime disguised as democracy.
Spain cannot afford this path. It is a democratic duty to remove issues as serious as the forest fires from the partisan trenches.
Otherwise, we run the risk that what is being burned are not only our forests, but also the foundations of our democracy.

urn:contentItem:6G4D-T8T3-RTV0-33W2-00000-00EU Audit Finds Flaws in Forest Fire Funding, Calls for Greater Focus on Prevention and Results2025-06-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisEU Audit Finds Flaws in Forest Fire Funding, Calls for Greater Focus on Prevention and ResultsTargeted News ServiceBRUSSELS, Belgium

(TNSLrpt) -- A new Special Report from the European Court of Auditors (ECA) has found that while European Union (EU) funds are increasingly being used by member states for forest fire prevention, there is "insufficient evidence of results and their long-term sustainability." The report, "EU funding to tackle forest fires," published on June 16, 2025, scrutinises how the European Commission and member states have managed EU funding in this critical area.

The ECA, led by the audit team of Henriette Tabbert, Kaye Dunnet, Matt Halliday, Rosemary Hill, and Tom Tyson, under the direction of Lee Summerfield, highlighted that forest fires burn an average of 353,000 hectares per year in the EU, releasing CO2, causing biodiversity loss, human casualties, and economic losses estimated at around Euros2 billion annually.

The report notes a positive shift, stating that "member states increasingly chose EU funding for prevention," a move experts consider "a necessary shift to reduce the likelihood and impact of future fires." This trend was observed in Greece, Portugal, and two regions in Spain. For instance, Portugal's investment in prevention has exceeded firefighting efforts since 2020, with the percentage spent on prevention rising from 20% in 2017 to 61% in 2022.

However, a significant shortcoming identified is the Commission's incomplete overview of EU spending on forest fire measures. "Forest fires are only one type of natural disaster, and the member states are not always required to differentiate between these and other types of natural disaster when reporting to the Commission on the amounts spent," the report explains.

The auditors also found issues with the rapid allocation of Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) funding for forest fires. In Greece and Portugal, RRF funds, amounting to Euros837 million and Euros615 million respectively, were sometimes allocated "in a hurry, without proper consultation or clear priorities." For example, in Portugal, the designated rural fire management agency was not involved in decisions for a Euros270 million measure.

Furthermore, the ECA identified "shortcomings in the selection process at member-state level," which creates a risk that "support may not be channelled to the projects that best address identified needs." This includes project selection sometimes being based on "outdated fire risk assessments," such as a 1980 map still in use in Greece. In two regions visited, project selection prioritized "geographical coverage over project quality," leading to a potentially "sub-optimal selection of projects."

The report also raises concerns about the long-term sustainability of financed actions, especially RRF-funded prevention projects, which require substantial future funding commitments from national budgets. The sampled research or demonstration projects were often "unsuccessful, delayed or not scaled up."

In light of these findings, the ECA issued two key recommendations. Firstly, the Commission should "promote good practices for EU funds to target projects with the greatest potential impact," by encouraging the use of clear and up-to-date risk maps, considering long-term sustainability, and balancing geographical coverage with risk-based criteria. This recommendation has a target implementation date of 2026.

Secondly, the Commission should "assess results and disseminate information on effective actions," including utilizing the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) data, disseminating information on successful research projects, and providing good practices for designing measures to member states. This also has a target implementation date of 2026.

-- Moira Sirois, Targeted News Service

urn:contentItem:6GBF-5FY3-RRVT-T112-00000-00Study Findings from National University of Science and Technology Broaden Understanding of Electronic Imaging (Lightweight Distilled Transformer-based Vision Framework for Detection of Forest Fire and Smoke In Real-world Scenes)2025-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisIMAGING TECHNOLOGY - ELECTRONIC IMAGINGStudy Findings from National University of Science and Technology Broaden Understanding of Electronic Imaging (Lightweight Distilled Transformer-based Vision Framework for Detection of Forest Fire and Smoke In Real-world Scenes)


2025 JUL 24 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Middle East Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Imaging Technology - Electronic Imaging. According to news reporting out of Islamabad, Pakistan, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires have become a ravaging threat with incidents growing rapidly across the globe. Several approaches for forest fire detection have been presented over the years; however, the need remains for an effective, computationally efficient, and unified vision-based solution, which can easily be deployable on edge devices for real-world applications."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the National University of Science and Technology, "To this end, we present a lightweight model based on a distilled vision transformer (D-ViT) to classify forest imagery into fire, smoke, and normal scenarios. We used ResNet50 as a teacher model trained on the target dataset and a compressed D-ViT as a student model trained using the knowledge distillation approach. Unlike existing approaches, the proposed D-ViT framework is computationally efficient with fewer trainable parameters and is unified in terms of detecting both fire and smoke (whichever is dominant) at longer ranges with visible imagery in the scene. For experimental validation, we deployed the model on the Jetson Nano board and performed an extensive evaluation and analysis of the proposed framework on data collected from public online sources, which we have made available on request for use by the research community. The proposed D-ViT model achieves an encouraging performance with a processing speed of 18.84 frames per second and an accuracy of 94% using soft distillation, thus demonstrating a performance improvement over the 90% accuracy obtained with the ViT (without distillation)."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "A comparison with several other standard deep classification models also shows encouraging results, with a better trade-off between accuracy and computational efficiency."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Lightweight Distilled Transformer-based Vision Framework for Detection of Forest Fire and Smoke In Real-world Scenes. Journal of Electronic Imaging, 2025;34(3). Journal of Electronic Imaging can be contacted at: Spie-soc Photo-optical Instrumentation Engineers, 1000 20TH St, PO Box 10, Bellingham, WA 98225, USA.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Tahir Nawaz, National University of Science and Technology, College of Electrical & Mechanical Engineering, Dept. of Mechatronics Engineering, Islamabad, Pakistan. Additional authors for this research include Hassan Akbar, Faisal Shafait, Md Asaduzzaman, Mohammad S. Hasan and Waqar Shahid Qureshi.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1117/1.JEI.34.3.033035. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6FYJ-MYG3-RRKM-W37X-00000-00Fujian Agricultural and Forestry University Reports Findings in Applied Ecology (Small-scale forest fire risk zoning based on bivariate statistics and multi-criteria decision analysis)2025-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:14ZLexisNexisECOLOGY - APPLIED ECOLOGYFujian Agricultural and Forestry University Reports Findings in Applied Ecology (Small-scale forest fire risk zoning based on bivariate statistics and multi-criteria decision analysis)


2025 JUN 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- New research on Ecology - Applied Ecology is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Fuzhou, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Fires pose serious threats to human life, forest environments, and biodiversity. Small-scale regional forest fire risk mapping is crucial for fire management."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Fujian Agricultural and Forestry University, "We combined bivariate statistics (weight of evidence, WOE, statistical index, SI) with multi-criteria decision analysis (analytic hierarchy process, AHP, analytic network process, ANP) to construct new WOE-ANP and SI-ANP comprehensive models to conduct forest fire risk zoning in Wangmo County, Guizhou Province. The results showed that most areas in the southern, western, and northern parts of Wangmo County were highly prone to forest fires, with fire risk of regions classified as level 4 or above accounting for 39.2%. Fire risk was severe in the county. The comprehensive models effectively enhanced the predictive ability of single bivariate statistical models. Compared to AHP, ANP provided more reliable assessments for the weight of forest fire risk factors."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The WOE-ANP and SI-ANP comprehensive models demonstrated high accuracy (84.3% and 83.8%, respectively) in assessing forest fire risk, offering more reliable decision support and reference for forest fire management."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Small-scale forest fire risk zoning based on bivariate statistics and multi-criteria decision analysis. Ying Yong Sheng Tai Xue Bao, 2025;36(1):187-196.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Chun-Hui Li, College of Fores-try, Fujian Agricultural and Forestry University, Fuzhou 350002, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Yi-Yun Ouyang, Rong-Yu Ni, Ping-Xin Zhao, Ai-Cong Zeng and Fu-Tao Guo.
Keywords for this news article include: Fuzhou, People's Republic of China, Asia, Applied Ecology, Ecology, Risk and Prevention.
